title: State v. White
description: Nickie White appeals his conviction for criminal sexual conduct in the first degree and kidnapping, arguing the circuit court erred (1) in refusing to charge assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature and simple assualt and battery as lesser-included offenses of criminal sexual conduct, and (2) in admitting the testimony of the State's expert on post-traumatic stress disorder and sexual abuse.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Nickie White, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3604
Heard January 14, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  3, 2003

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
& REMANDED 


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Katherine Carruth Link, of Columbia; 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; Warren Blair 
  Giese, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Following a jury trial, Nickie 
  White was convicted of criminal sexual conduct in the first degree and kidnapping.Â  
  He was sentenced to consecutive prison terms of thirty years for criminal sexual 
  conduct and ten years for kidnapping.Â  White appeals, arguing the circuit court 
  erred (1) in refusing to charge assault and battery of a high and aggravated 
  nature (ABHAN) and simple assault and battery as lesser-included offenses of 
  criminal sexual conduct, and (2) in admitting the testimony of the Stateâ€™s expert 
  on post-traumatic stress disorder and sexual abuse.Â  We affirm in part and reverse 
  in part.
FACTS
The victim was employed as a bartender at Club 
  Palace in Columbia. During the course of her employment, White was a customer 
  of the club.Â  The victim often engaged in conversation with White while she 
  was working.Â  On July 31, 1998, White went to Club Palace.Â  When White arrived, 
  the victim hugged him and later danced with him during the evening.Â  At some 
  point during her shift they left together to get change.Â  The victim and White 
  went to a nearby Wal-Mart for change; while there they entered a photo booth 
  and took several instant photographs together.Â  Afterwards, the victim agreed 
  to go to breakfast with White when she got off work.Â  According to the victim, 
  however, she changed her mind about breakfast because she had not made much 
  money that night and was tired.Â Â Â Â  Nevertheless, she agreed to drive White 
  home to his grandmotherâ€™s house.Â  Upon arriving at the home, White went inside 
  to check on his grandmother and then returned to the car where the victim was 
  waiting.Â  
At this point, both the victim and White testified 
  to a different version of the events that occurred afterwards.Â  According to 
  the victim, White asked her to drive him to a nearby store for a soda.Â  She 
  testified that when they returned to the house, White pulled a knife on her 
  and demanded that she drive to Earlewood Park.Â  She testified that White sexually 
  assaulted and raped her there, but that she was eventually able to seize the 
  knife and stab him forcing him to flee.Â  The victim stated that she followed 
  him out of the park â€œto make sure that he stayed, he didnâ€™t try and come back 
  to get me.â€Â  
According to White, the victim suggested they go 
  to the park to watch the sun rise.Â  He stated he took a knife for protection 
  because of the parkâ€™s location.Â  He testified that the victim made sexual advances 
  towards him at the park and they engaged in consensual intercourse.Â  He added 
  that she became angry when he wanted to stop, cursed at him, grabbed the knife, 
  and then stabbed him.Â  He further stated that she followed him out of the woods 
  when he turned to leave, and â€œcame behind [him], charging.â€Â  One of the witnesses 
  who transported the victim to the hospital after the incident testified that 
  when he saw them, the victim was following after White as he walked past him.Â  

White was indicted for kidnapping 
  and first degree criminal sexual conduct in connection with the incident. [1] Â  He was found guilty of both charges and was 
  sentenced to consecutive sentences of thirty years imprisonment for criminal 
  sexual conduct and ten years for kidnapping.Â  White appeals, arguing the circuit 
  court erred in failing to charge ABHAN and simple assault and battery as lesser 
  included offenses of first degree CSC, and in admitting the testimony of the 
  Stateâ€™s expert witness on post-traumatic stress disorder and sexual abuse.
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Jury Charge on ABHAN
At the close of the case, White requested a jury charge on 
  assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) as a lesser-included 
  offense of criminal sexual conduct in the first degree. 
  [2] Â  The circuit court denied the requested charge.Â  White argues this 
  was error because the requested charge was supported by the evidence.Â  We agree.
ABHAN â€œis an unlawful act of violent injury accompanied 
  by circumstances of aggravation.â€Â  State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 580, 
  564 S.E.2d 103, 105 (2002) (citation omitted).Â  â€œâ€˜Circumstances of aggravationâ€™ 
  is an element of ABHAN.â€Â  Id. (citation omitted).Â  â€œCircumstances of 
  aggravation include the use of a deadly weapon, the intent to commit a felony, 
  infliction of serious bodily injury, great disparity in the ages or physical 
  conditions of the parties, a difference in gender, the purposeful infliction 
  of shame and disgrace, taking indecent liberties or familiarities with a female, 
  and resistance to lawful authority.â€Â  Id. at 105-106, 564 S.E.2d at 580-581.
Our supreme court has recently held that ABHAN is a 
  lesser- included offense of first degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  Primus, 
  349 S.C. at 581, 564 S.E.2d at 106.Â  A â€œtrial judge must charge a lesser included 
  offense if there is any evidence from which it can be inferred that the defendant 
  committed the lesser included of the crime charged.â€Â  State v. Heyward, 
  350 S.C. 153, 157, 564 S.E.2d 379, 381 (Ct. App. 2002), cert. denied 
  Nov. 6, 2002, (citing State v. Drafts, 288 S.C. 30, 32, 340 S.E.2d 784, 
  785 (1986)).Â  â€œTo warrant eliminating a lesser included offense charge, it must 
  â€˜very clearly appear that there is no evidence whatsoeverâ€™ tending to 
  reduce the crime from the greater offense to the lesser.â€Â  Heyward, 350 
  S.C. at 158, 564 S.E.2d at 382 (citation omitted) (emphasis added in the original).Â  

In both Heyward and Drafts, the issue 
  was whether the trial judge erred in failing to issue an ABHAN charge where 
  the defendant was on trial for assault with intent to commit criminal sexual 
  conduct in the first degree.Â  Id. at 157, 564 S.E.2d at 381.Â  In both 
  cases, there was evidence from which a jury could find the defendant was guilty 
  of ABHAN, and thus the trial judge erred in not charging ABHAN.Â  Heyward, 
  350 S.C. at 158, 564 S.E.2d at 382; Drafts, 288 S.C. at 34, 340 S.E.2d 
  at 786.Â  In Drafts, the defendant allegedly held the victim at knifepoint 
  and asked her to â€œgive him a little bitâ€ and perform oral sex.Â  The defendant, 
  however, claimed that â€œhe did not want to do anythingâ€ with the victim, but 
  admitted taking indecent liberties with her.Â  Our supreme court found that if 
  the jury had believed the defendant â€œdid not want to do anything with the victim, 
  they could have concluded there was no sexual battery and found him guilty of 
  ABHAN.â€Â  Drafts, 288 S.C. at 34, 340 S.E.2d at 786.Â  Similarly, in Heyward, 
  after beating the victim about the head and choking her, the defendant allegedly 
  forced the victim into her car and told her he was taking her for a ride â€œto 
  get some of [her] good stuff.â€Â  Heyward, 350 S.C. at 156, 340 S.E.2d 
  at 381.Â  This court found it could not â€œisolate Heywardâ€™s single statement concerning 
  Victimâ€™s â€˜good stuffâ€™ to the exclusion of the evidence that Heyward was guilty 
  only of ABHAN.â€Â  Id. at 158, 340 S.E.2d at 382.Â Â  
In the present case, the victim testified that prior 
  to the commission of the alleged CSC, White dragged her into the woods by her 
  arms while holding the knife and then punched her in her eye.Â  She further stated 
  that during the alleged CSC, White â€œgot mad and slapped [her].â€Â Â Â  Thus, 
  under the victimâ€™s version of events, a charge for ABHAN would have been proper 
  because it was contemporaneous with the alleged CSC.Â  
White testified that he and the victim had consensual 
  sexual intercourse.Â  Under his version of events, because the sex was consensual, 
  no battery could have occurred until after he and the victim had sex.Â  White 
  admitted that he struck the victim in self-defense when she became angry with 
  him for withdrawing from sex.Â  Thus, because there was evidence from which the 
  jury could have believed that the sex was consensual, and that no battery occurred 
  until after the parties engaged in intercourse, we find White was entitled to 
  an ABHAN charge.Â  Accordingly, we reverse Whiteâ€™s first degree CSC conviction 
  and remand this issue to the circuit court for a new trial.
  II.              
Jury Charge on Simple Assault 
   
White also asserts the trial court erred in refusing 
  to charge simple assault and battery as a lesser included offense of CSC.Â  We 
  disagree.Â  
â€œ[S]imple assault and battery is an unlawful act of 
  violent injury to another, unaccompanied by any circumstances of aggravation.â€Â  
  State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 21, 518 S.E.2d 278, 285 (Ct. App. 1999) 
  (quoting State v. Sprouse, 325 S.C. 275, 285-86, 478 S.E.2d 871, 877 
  (Ct. App. 1996)).Â  Among other things, an example of a circumstance of aggravation 
  includes a difference in the sexes.Â  Id.Â  In this case, we find no error 
  in the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to charge simple assault and battery.Â  Here, the 
  evidence shows that the parties were of opposite sexes, an aggravating circumstance 
  of ABHAN.Â  Therefore, a circumstance of aggravation existed in this factual 
  scenario to take this case outside of the realm of simple assault and battery.
III.Â  Testimony of Stateâ€™s Expert Witness
White next argues the circuit court erred in admitting 
  the testimony of the Stateâ€™s expert witness, Coles Badger, on post-traumatic 
  stress disorder and sexual abuse because it was more prejudicial than probative.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
As an initial matter, we 
  address the preservation of this issue for our review.Â  During a motion in 
  limine, Whiteâ€™s attorney objected to Badgerâ€™s testimony, arguing its prejudicial 
  effect would greatly outweigh its probative value.Â  After arguments on this 
  issue, the circuit court stated it would â€œtake a look at the cases [on the issue] 
  and then [make] a determination before [court] started back.â€Â  However, before 
  there was a ruling on the admissibility of Badgerâ€™s testimony, another witness 
  testified.Â  Badger then testified in camera, and Whiteâ€™s attorney again 
  objected to her testimony, this time based on the ground that she was not qualified.Â  
  After hearing arguments from both sides, the circuit court ruled Badger could 
  be admitted as an expert in the fields of post-traumatic stress disorder and 
  sexual abuse.Â  The circuit court also noted for the record that it â€œmade an 
  analysis under Rule 403 and . . . deemed that the testimony would be appropriate.â€Â  
  Thus, we find the circuit court made a final ruling on Whiteâ€™s in limine 
  Rule 403 objection.Â  Therefore, this issue is properly preserved for our review.Â  
  See State v. Smith, 337 S.C. 27, 32, 522 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1999) 
  (â€œA ruling in limine is not final; unless an objection is made at the 
  time the evidence is offered and a final ruling is procured, the issue is not 
  preserved for review.â€) (citation omitted).
At trial, Badger testified that in her opinion, the victimâ€™s symptoms were consistent 
  with someone who had suffered trauma and had been raped.Â  Badger explained that 
  the victim â€œdescribed symptoms of being unable to sleep and of having nightmares, 
  having difficulty concentrating, being very fearful, unable to trust others.â€Â  
  She further testified about the victimâ€™s â€œjumpiness,â€ â€œanger,â€ â€œshame,â€ â€œcrying,â€ 
  and â€œanxiety.â€Â  
White argues Badgerâ€™s testimony 
  was more prejudicial than probative because it was outside the scope of the 
  exception for rape trauma evidence as carved out by State v. Schumpert, 
  312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993), and its progeny.Â  White contends this case 
  is distinguishable from those cases which allow expert rape trauma testimony 
  because the victim in this case was an adult.Â  White argues the victim was neither 
  a person whose ability to discuss the facts and circumstances of the case would 
  prevent her from coming forward for fear of reprisal nor someone whose age, 
  inexperience, and impressionability might make it difficult to accurately remember 
  the events because of an immaturity or lack of understanding with the judicial 
  process.Â  More succinctly stated, White claims the reasons for the exception 
  in Schumpert simply do not exist in this case.Â  
We could discern no case 
  in this state which has held that the Schumpert exception applies only 
  to child victims.Â  Neither Schumpert nor any of its progeny limits the 
  use of rape trauma evidence to cases involving child sexual assault victims.Â  
  Accordingly, we decline to limit the use of this testimony to cases where the 
  sexual conduct involves a minor.
Moreover, we find this testimony was cumulative to the unchallenged testimony 
  of Dr. Alfred Jenkins, Nurse Bridgette Deguzman, and Officer Bob Benson.Â  Dr. 
  Jenkins, who observed the victim in the emergency room after the incident, testified 
  that at that time she was â€œquite tearful,â€ â€œagitated,â€ and â€œwithdrawn.â€Â  He 
  stated in his opinion, she had suffered trauma.Â  Nurse Deguzman, who also saw 
  the victim in the emergency room after the incident, stated that when she first 
  saw her, the victim â€œwas upset and she appeared frightened, disheveled; she 
  was crying, visibly shaken.â€Â  Officer Benson testified that when the victim 
  wrote her statement approximately two days after the incident, she would write 
  a few pages and then get upset.Â  
Given the testimony of these witnesses, any error in admitting Badgerâ€™s testimony 
  was harmless.Â  See Schumpert, 312 S.C. at 507, 435 S.E.2d at 862 
  (stating that any error in the admission of cumulative evidence is harmless); 
  State v. Johnson, 298 S.C. 496, 499, 381 S.E.2d 732, 733 (1989) (â€œThe 
  admission of improper evidence is harmless where it is merely cumulative to 
  other evidence.â€).
Finally, White argues that the prejudicial effect of Badgerâ€™s testimony, that 
  she believed the victimâ€™s account of events, far outweighed its probative value 
  and improperly bolstered the victimâ€™s testimony.Â  Essentially, White argues 
  that this testimony â€œtipped the scalesâ€ in the victimâ€™s favor, and therefore 
  White should be entitled to a new trial on the kidnapping charge as well.Â  
  Although this testimony may have exceeded the proper boundaries of expert 
  testimony regarding post-traumatic stress and sexual abuse under State v. 
  Dawkins, 297 S.C. 386, 377 S.E.2d 298 (1989) and its progeny, we find this 
  issue is not preserved for our review as Whiteâ€™s attorney failed to object to 
  this testimony when it was elicited during trial.Â  See State v. Peay, 
  321 S.C. 405, 413, 468 S.E.2d 669, 674 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding a contemporaneous 
  objection and ruling at trial is required to properly preserve an error for 
  appellate review).Â  Thus, we decline to address this issue on appeal and necessarily 
  hold that Whiteâ€™s kidnapping conviction is affirmed.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing reasons, we find White was entitled 
  to an ABHAN charge and accordingly, we reverse Whiteâ€™s CSC conviction and remand 
  that issue to the circuit court for a new trial consistent with this opinion.Â 
We further find the circuit court did not err in failing to charge simple assault 
  and battery and in admitting the testimony of the Stateâ€™s expert witness; therefore, 
  we affirm Whiteâ€™s kidnapping conviction. [3]   
AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part, and REMANDED 
  for a new trial.
CURETON and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.  

 
   
     
    [1]    White was also indicted for armed robbery and possession of marijuana; 
    however, the jury found him not guilty of these charges.Â  

 
    [2]    Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-652 (Supp. 2001):Â  
  
  
  (1) A person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the first 
    degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with the victim and if any one 
    or more of the following circumstances are proven:
  (a) The actor uses aggravated force to accomplish sexual battery.
  (b) The victim submits to sexual 
    battery by the actor under circumstances where the victim is also the victim 
    of forcible confinement, kidnapping, robbery, extortion, burglary, housebreaking, 
    or any other similar offense or act.
  (c) The actor causes the victim, without the victimâ€™s consent, 
    to become mentally incapacitated or physically helpless by administering, 
    distributing, dispensing, delivering, or causing to be administered, distributed, 
    dispensed, or delivered a controlled substance, a controlled substance analogue, 
    or any intoxicating substance.
  

 
   
    [3]  We note that in Drafts, our supreme court let a conviction 
    for kidnapping stand where a conviction for CSC was reversed and remanded 
    for a new trial for failure to charge ABHAN.Â  Drafts, 288 S.C. at 34, 
    340 S.E.2d at 786.Â Â Â

title: Purdy v. Purdy
description: This case involves the issue of whether the family court erred in refusing to terminate his child support obligation for his minor daughter where the father asserted the daughter was emancipated.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Henry K. Purdy, III, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Catherine A. Purdy, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3605
Submitted January 13, 2003 - Filed March 
  3, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
H. Fred Kuhn, of Beaufort; for Appellant.
Edwin W. Rowland, of Hilton Head Island; for Respondent.
      
    
  


HUFF, J.:Â  Henry K. Purdy, III (the father) 
  appeals from an order of the family court refusing to terminate his child support 
  obligation to Catherine A. Purdy (the mother) before the partiesâ€™ child reached 
  the age of majority.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The parties were formerly married.Â  
  Their youngest child, Ryan, who was born March 15, 1984, is the subject of this 
  action.Â  The mother and father were divorced by order of the family court dated 
  October 30, 1995.Â  Pursuant to the order, the parties were awarded joint custody 
  of Ryan, with the mother designated the primary custodial parent.Â  The family 
  court set the fatherâ€™s monthly child support at $1,500 for Ryan and her older 
  sister.Â  At the time of the instant action, the fatherâ€™s child support obligation 
  was $750 per month, inasmuch as Ryanâ€™s sister had already reached majority.
The father instituted this action against the mother 
  on February 28, 2001 seeking an order declaring Ryan emancipated and terminating 
  his child support obligation.Â  The mother answered, denying that Ryan was emancipated.
The family court held the final hearing 
  on the matter on May 14, 2001, at which time Ryan was still a minor.Â  Ryan testified 
  she quit school in late 2000 when she was in the eleventh grade.Â  Shortly thereafter, 
  on February 28, 2001, she moved out of the motherâ€™s home.Â  At the time of trial, 
  Ryan was living with her boyfriend and a roommate, and was pregnant with her 
  boyfriendâ€™s child.Â  Both she and her boyfriend were employed.Â  Ryan had been 
  employed for approximately two months by a hotel-resort baby-sitting service 
  on a part-time basis, working three or four days per week.Â  Ryan testified she 
  and her boyfriend paid their own rent, food and utility expenses without assistance 
  from the mother, and she intended to remain with her boyfriend after the birth 
  of their child.
The mother testified she wanted 
  what was best for her daughter.Â  While agreeing her daughter was â€œout on her 
  ownâ€ at that time, she noted Ryanâ€™s future was uncertain inasmuch as she was 
  still a minor and unmarried.Â  She noted she was concerned the boyfriend could 
  leave her daughter and she would then be responsible for both her daughter and 
  her grandchild.Â  She stated she did not want the child support money for herself, 
  and would turn any further child support payments over to Ryan.
By order dated May 25, 2001, the 
  family court declined to declare Ryan emancipated and ordered the father to 
  continue paying child support until Ryan became emancipated by reaching the 
  age of eighteen or getting married. 
  [1] Â  In reaching this determination, the trial court reasoned that there 
  was no credible evidence establishing Ryan was able to sustain herself.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has 
  the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 
  157, 160 (1992).Â  We are not, however, required to disregard the findings of 
  the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position 
  to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  
  Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 58, 552 S.E.2d 329, 334 (Ct. App. 
  2001);Â  Wilson v. Walker, 340 S.C. 531, 537, 532 S.E.2d 19, 22 (Ct. App. 
  2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Generally, under South Carolina law, 
  a parentâ€™s obligation to pay child support extends until the child reaches majority, 
  becomes self-supporting, or marries, then ends by operation of law.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(17) (Supp. 2002) (granting family court jurisdiction 
  â€œ[t]o make all orders for support run until further order of the court, except 
  that orders for child support run until the child is eighteen years of age or 
  until the child is married or becomes self-supporting, as determined by the 
  court, whichever occurs first . . . .â€).Â  â€œEmancipation of a minor child is 
  effected primarily by agreement of the parent, although acts of the child are 
  to be considered.â€Â  Timmerman v. Brown, 268 S.C. 303, 305, 233 S.E.2d 
  106, 107 (1977).Â  â€œWhether a child has been emancipated depends on the facts 
  and circumstances of each case.â€Â  Id.
At first glance, the acts of Ryan strongly suggest 
  emancipation, but when considered in light of other facts and circumstances, 
  we agree with the findings of the trial judge and defer to his wisdom and judgment 
  as to the lack of evidence establishing Ryanâ€™s full emancipation at the time 
  this action was commenced.Â  Although Ryan had moved out of the motherâ€™s home 
  and was residing with her boyfriend, it is clear from the record that the mother, 
  who is the primary custodial parent, objected to the move and clearly did not 
  agree that her daughter should be emancipated.Â  The mother testified the father 
  gave Ryan â€œmoney behind [the motherâ€™s] backâ€ in order to allow Ryan to move 
  out of her home.Â  The father himself testified he gave Ryan $700 for the â€œdown 
  paymentâ€ on her apartment, and took Ryan and her boyfriend to a store, spending 
  over $500 for them to â€œget whatever they needed for their apartment.â€ [2] Â  Further, Ryan and her boyfriend were not married 
  and, therefore, the boyfriend was not legally obligated to contribute to Ryanâ€™s 
  support.Â  While Ryan was employed on a part-time basis, there was no evidence 
  that she could have supported herself in the event her relationship with her 
  boyfriend deteriorated.Â  Additionally, the mother testified she had continued 
  to financially support her daughter, giving her cash, taking her out for meals, 
  paying for repairs to Ryanâ€™s car, and paying $100 toward Ryanâ€™s medical bill 
  until she could obtain reimbursement for the bill from Ryanâ€™s father.Â  Thus, 
  it appears Ryan, even with the help of her boyfriend, was not truly self-supporting.
CONCLUSION
Under the particular facts and circumstances of this case, 
  especially the fact that the primary custodial parent did not acquiesce in the 
  minorâ€™s move from the home but the supporting parent both consented and encouraged 
  the move with financial aide, we discern no error in the family courtâ€™s ruling.
For the foregoing reasons, the decision 
  of the family court is
 AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and SHULER, JJ., concur.




 
   [1] The 
    court further ordered that the support â€œshall be paid to the mother who in 
    turn will write a check to the child, Ryan Purdy.â€

 
    [2]
   It 
    should be noted the father filed this action on the same day the daughter 
    moved out of the motherâ€™s home. Â It appears the father is, in effect, attempting 
    to eliminate his monthly support obligation by financially enabling his daughter 
    to move out of the home of her mother against the motherâ€™s wishes.Â  While 
    we agree with the fatherâ€™s assertion that the provision of money to the child 
    under these circumstances tends to reward the minor for â€œquitting school, 
    moving in with her boyfriend, [and] getting pregnant,â€ the father is, in part, 
    the author of this problem.

description: Patsy Jordan (Mother) appeals from a family court order terminating her parental rights to minor child, Baby Boy Roe, and granting his adoption to Roe's foster mother, Jane Doe.  Mother argues that no ground existed to terminate her parental rights and that termination of her rights was not in Roe's best interests.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Jane Doe,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Baby Boy Roe, a minor under the age of fourteen (14) years, South Carolina 
        Department of Social Services, Eric Stern and Patsy Jordan,       
Defendants,
Of whom Patsy Jordan is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


 
Appeal From Greenville County
Â Amy C. Sutherland, Family Court Judge

 
Opinion No. 3606
Heard January 13, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  10, 2003Â Â 

 
AFFIRMED

 

  
    
      
Thomas L. Bruce, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Robert D. Moseley, Jr., of Greenville, 
  for Respondent.
Frances E. Duarte, of Greenville; for Guardian Ad
Litem.
      
    
  

  

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
HEARN, C.J.: Patsy Jordan (Mother) appeals 
  from a family court order terminating her parental rights to minor child, Baby 
  Boy Roe, and granting his adoption to Roeâ€™s foster mother, Jane Doe.Â  We affirm.Â  

FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On November 17, 1998, Mother gave birth to Roe, 
  who had illegal drugs in his system. 
  [1] Â  The next day, following the South Carolina Department of Social Servicesâ€™ 
  (DSS) assessment that Mother posed a â€œhigh riskâ€ of causing harm or physical 
  abuse to Roe, DSS and Mother entered into a safety plan in which she agreed 
  to seek substance abuse treatment.Â  Eight days after Roeâ€™s birth, DSS placed 
  him in protective custody.Â  Roe remained hospitalized until placed in a foster 
  home on December 8, 1998. 
At the time of Roeâ€™s birth, Mother was on probation 
  for drug and shoplifting offenses. By giving birth to a drug-addicted baby, 
  Mother violated her probation, so she was incarcerated from November 1998 until 
  July 1999.Â  
In May 1999, the family court, operating under 
  the assumption Mother had been released from jail, ordered Mother to pay monetary 
  support to Roe. However, a second family court order was issued, dismissing 
  Motherâ€™s child support obligation and noting Mother was â€œstill in jail when 
  that order was signed.â€Â  The family court also ordered Mother to undergo drug 
  and alcohol counseling and attend parenting classes. 
When Mother was released from jail in July, she 
  took very few steps toward regaining custody of Roe.Â  Although she did visit 
  Roe, she failed to attend both the recommended outpatient drug treatment program 
  and parenting classes. By October, Mother was incarcerated again for her tenth 
  shoplifting offense. 
Once Mother was released from prison in January 
  2000, she immediately went into a drug addiction recovery program and began 
  to turn her life around.Â  Mother completed a six-week parenting class in May 
  2000, and in June, after the family court ordered Mother to pay child support 
  for Roe, she began making payments.Â  
Doe initiated this action to 
  terminate Roeâ€™s parentsâ€™ parental rights on July 21, 2000.Â  Doe also sought 
  to adopt Roe.Â  
The family court terminated 
  Motherâ€™s rights based on the child remaining in foster care for fifteen of the 
  last twenty-two months and based on grounds of abandonment, failure to rehabilitate, 
  failure to support, failure to visit, and diagnosable condition. The 
  court also approved Doeâ€™s adoption of Roe, concluding the adoption was in Roeâ€™s 
  best interests.Â  Mother appeals, arguing that no ground existed to support the 
  termination of her parental rights and that termination was not in Roeâ€™s best 
  interests.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a termination of parental rights (TPR) case, 
  the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.Â  South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 
  287 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing 
  evidence.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 
  (1999); see also Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 747-48 (1982) 
  (â€œBefore a State may sever completely and irrevocably the rights of parents 
  in their natural child, due process requires that the State support its allegations 
  by at least clear and convincing evidence.â€).
Furthermore, in a TPR case, the appellate court 
  has jurisdiction to examine the entire record to determine the facts according 
  to its view of the evidence.Â  Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 
  330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 866 (1998).Â  This court may review the record 
  and make its own findings whether clear and convincing evidence supports termination.Â  
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 
  S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999). However, our broad scope of review does not 
  require us to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact the trial judge 
  was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Dorchester 
  County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 
  480 (Ct. App. 1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Under South Carolinaâ€™s TPR Statute, â€œ[t]he family 
  court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one 
  or more of the [listed] grounds and a finding that termination is in the 
  best interest of the child.â€ S.C. Code Â§ 20-7-1572 (2001) (emphasis added).Â  
  Thus, to terminate parental rights under section 20-7-1572, the family court 
  must first find at least one of the statutory grounds set forth in that section.Â  
  If the family court finds that a statutory ground for termination has been proven, 
  it must then find that the best interests of the child would be served by termination.Â  
  Id.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Grounds for Terminating Motherâ€™s Parental Rights
One ground for terminating a 
  parentâ€™s rights under section 20-7-1572 is that the child has lived in foster 
  care for fifteen out of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  In this case, Roe 
  had been in emergency protective custody and foster care since he was eight 
  days old.Â  At the time his foster mother sought to terminate his parentsâ€™ rights, 
  Roe was twenty-months old.Â  Mother argues that because twenty-two months had 
  not expired, her rights cannot be terminated on this ground.Â  We disagree.
When construing a statute, courts 
  should consider the words of the statute in conjunction with the purpose of 
  the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. 
  Servs. v. Gamble, 337 S.C. 428, 523 S.E.2d 477 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The stated 
  purpose of South Carolinaâ€™s TPR statute â€œis to establish procedures for the 
  reasonable and compassionate termination of parental rights where children are 
  abused, neglected, or abandoned in order to protect the health and welfare of 
  such children and make them eligible for adoption . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  20-7-1560 (1976).Â  Furthermore, case law tells us that TPR statutes must be 
  liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing 
  minor children from the custody and control of their parents by terminating 
  the parent-child relationship.Â  Joiner ex. rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 
  102, 108, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. 
  v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 519 S.E.2d 351 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
With the purpose of the TPR statute in mind, we 
  find that once a child has been in foster care for fifteen months, whether those 
  months are consecutive or within the last twenty-two months, the parental rights 
  of that childâ€™s parents may be terminated upon a showing that termination is 
  in the childâ€™s best interests.Â  We believe the legislature included the â€œwithin 
  the most recent twenty-two monthsâ€ language in order to account for children 
  who bounce between a foster home and their parentsâ€™ home.Â  The language indicates 
  that children need not have been in foster care for fifteen consecutive months 
  before their parentsâ€™ rights can be terminated, but rather, a ground for termination 
  exists once a child has languished in foster care for any fifteen months 
  within the most recent twenty-two-month period.Â Â  
Here, the fact that Roe was in foster care for 
  the last twenty months is undisputed.Â  Thus, we find the trial court did not 
  err in finding a statutory ground supporting the termination of Motherâ€™s parental 
  rights.
II.Â  Roeâ€™s Best Interests
Having found one ground on which 
  the family court properly terminated Motherâ€™s parental rights, we need only 
  determine that termination of Motherâ€™s rights is in Roeâ€™s best interests to 
  affirm the family courtâ€™s termination.Â  See S.C. Code Â§ 20-7-1572.Â Â  Although 
  we applaud Mother for completing drug rehabilitation and for turning her life 
  around, we believe that Roeâ€™s interests would be best served by terminating 
  Motherâ€™s rights.Â  See e.g., South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. 
  Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 258-259, 519 S.E.2d 351, 356 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œThe 
  interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interests and the parental 
  rights conflict.â€).
 From the time that Roe was released 
  from the hospital, he resided with Doe, and at the time of the hearing, he was 
  just under twenty-nine months old.Â  DSS professionals testified about the bonds 
  he formed with Doe, as well as the quality of home-life provided by Doe.Â  A 
  behavioral pediatrician testified about the detrimental effect separating Roe 
  and Doe would have on Roe.Â  Additionally, Doe testified about her relationship 
  with Roe and her ability to provide a nurturing, safe, and comfortable home 
  for him.Â  Thus, we find ample evidence in the record to support the family courtâ€™s 
  termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights.
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the 
  decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
CURETON and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Mother also gave birth to a drug-addicted baby 
    in 1992.

 THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
 The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Marion L. Parris,       
Appellant.
      
    
  

__________
Appeal From Cherokee County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
__________
Opinion No. 3607
Heard November 11, 2002 â€“ Filed March 
  10, 2003
__________
REVERSED
__________

  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  and Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

__________
 SHULER, J.:Â  Marion L. 
  Parris appeals his conviction for breach of trust with fraudulent intent, arguing 
  the trial court erred in failing to grant his motion for a directed verdict.Â  
  We agree and reverse.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Marion Parris owned and operated Parris 
  Home Sales (PHS), a mobile home dealership in Gaffney.Â  PHS had a financing 
  arrangement with First National Bank which included a $750,000 â€œfloor planâ€ 
  line of credit for the pre-approved purchase of mobile homes.Â  As security, 
  First National had a blanket lien over all PHS business assets.Â  In addition, 
  although titles1 to the mobile homes in the companyâ€™s 
  inventory originated in PHS, First National maintained physical possession of 
  all titles until each unit was sold.Â  Upon receipt of payment for its interest, 
  First National transferred possession of the title to either the buyer, if the 
  transaction was a cash sale, or, as was usually the case, the permanent lender 
  financing the purchase.Â  
On February 3, 1999, PHS executed a note 
  to First National for $37,405 to purchase a new double-wide mobile home.Â  The 
  loan agreement authorized PHS to pay only accrued interest, in monthly installments, 
  until February 5, 2000, at which time the entire principal amount would come 
  due.Â  The agreement further provided, in part, that PHS would be in default 
  if it did or failed to do something causing the bank to believe it would have 
  difficulty collecting the amount owed.Â  In case of default, the agreement outlined 
  four enumerated remedies plus â€œany remedy . . . under state or federal law.â€ 

On November 1, 1999, Jerry and Sherry 
  Martin signed a purchase agreement for the mobile home bought by PHS with proceeds 
  from the February 3rd loan.Â  The contract listed a purchase price of $40,340 
  and stated in pertinent part:Â  

Title to said [mobile home] shall remain in the Seller until 
  the agreed purchase price therefor [sic] is paid in full 9 in cash or by the 
  execution of a 9 Retail Installment Contract, or a Security Agreement and its 
  acceptance by a financing agency; thereupon title to the within described unit 
  passes to the buyer as of the date of either full cash payment or on the signing 
  of said credit instruments even though the actual physical delivery may not 
  be made until a later date.Â  

The sale was consummated on November 
  18, 1999, when the Martinsâ€™ lender, Bank of America, issued two checks totaling 
  $40,340 and jointly payable to Jerry Martin and PHS.Â  Pursuant to the terms 
  of the purchase agreement, title to the mobile home passed to the Martins at 
  this time, albeit subject to First Nationalâ€™s outstanding lien.Â  Jerry Martin 
  thereafter endorsed the checks and Marcia Jolly, the bank vice president conducting 
  the loan closing, handed them to Parris.Â  Parris told the Martins to â€œgive him 
  a couple of days and he would have everything done and [they] could be moved 
  in by Thanksgiving,â€ then left the bank.Â  The Martins subsequently accepted 
  delivery and took possession of the mobile home on the day before Thanksgiving. 

The next day, November 19, Parris opened 
  a checking account with American Federal Bank and deposited the two checks from 
  Bank of America.Â  Thereafter, he withdrew money and wrote checks on the account 
  to himself, PHS, and various other payees; he also deposited an additional $7,858.29 
  into the account.Â  
On December 6, Sherry Martin noticed 
  First Nationalâ€™s president, Steve Moss, â€œsnoopingâ€ around the new mobile home.Â  
  Moss approached, knocked on the door, and asked Martin for the trailerâ€™s serial 
  number.Â  When Martin told Moss the number was none of his business, Moss replied 
  â€œthat he had a right to get the serial number, that he owned the home, and that 
  he could repossess it.â€Â  Sherry Martin, upset and crying, called her husband 
  and told him what Moss had said.Â  
Jerry Martin immediately drove to First 
  National and discussed the matter with Thomas Hale, the bankâ€™s Chief Lending 
  Officer.Â  Hale explained that First National still had the title to the trailer 
  because Parris had not yet paid off the note.Â  When Martin asked if the bank 
  could really take possession of the home, he was told it could and â€œprobably 
  would.â€Â  Hale then directed Martin to hire a lawyer and go to the police.Â  The 
  Martins did so and the police subsequently arrested and charged Parris with 
  breach of trust with fraudulent intent.Â  Following the arrest, First National 
  accelerated the underlying note and seized PHSâ€™s business assets, which it later 
  sold at a discount.Â Â  
On February 24, 2000, a Cherokee County 
  grand jury indicted Parris for breach of trust with fraudulent intent.Â  Following 
  conviction by a jury on July 25, 2000, the trial court sentenced Parris to ten 
  years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Standard of Review
In ruling on a motion for directed verdict 
  in a criminal case, a trial court must view the evidence in the light most favorable 
  to the State.Â  See State v. Buckmon, 347 S.C. 316, 555 S.E.2d 
  402 (2001).Â  In so doing, the court is concerned with the existence of evidence, 
  not its weight.Â  State v. Lollis, 343 S.C. 580, 541 S.E.2d 254 (2001).Â  
  This Court, in reviewing a refusal to grant the motion, must also view the evidence 
  in a light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. McGowan, 347 S.C. 618, 
  557 S.E.2d 657 (2001).Â  If the record reveals any direct or substantial circumstantial 
  evidence which reasonably tends to prove guilt, then this Court must find the 
  trial court acted properly in submitting the case to the jury.Â  See Buckmon, 
  347 S.C. at 321, 555 S.E.2d at 404; Lollis, 343 S.C. at 584, 541 S.E.2d 
  at 256.Â 
On the other hand, if the State fails 
  to present sufficient evidence of the offense, a defendant is entitled to a 
  directed verdict from the court.Â  State v. Walker, 349 S.C. 49, 562 S.E.2d 
  313 (2002).Â  Hence, â€œwhere the facts of the case, even if proved, do not constitute 
  the alleged criminal conduct, a directed verdict must be granted.â€Â  State 
  v. Jackson, 338 S.C. 565, 569, 527 S.E.2d 367, 369 (Ct. App. 2000).
Discussion
Parris argues 
  the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict because the State failed 
  to prove he committed a breach of trust.Â  We agree.Â  
Although our Legislature has partially 
  codified the offense of breach of trust with fraudulent intent, its elements 
  remain defined by case law.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-230 (Supp. 2002).Â  
  In essence, the crime is â€œlarceny after trust, which includes all of the elements 
  of larceny or in common parlance, stealing, except the unlawful taking in the 
  beginning.â€Â  State v. Scott, 330 S.C. 125, 130, 497 S.E.2d 735, 738 (1998) 
  (quoting State v. Owings, 205 S.C. 314, 316, 31 S.E.2d 906, 907 (1944)).Â  
  The fact distinguishing larceny from breach of trust is that possession of the 
  property is gained by unlawful means in larceny while a breach of trust is accomplished 
  by a lawful taking of the property, i.e., through its entrustment to 
  one by another.2Â Â  See Scott, 330 S.C. at 130, 
  497 S.E.2d at 738. 
To sustain a conviction, the State must 
  prove every element of the offense charged.Â  Jackson, 338 S.C. at 569, 
  527 S.E.2d at 369.Â  In breach of trust cases, the central question is whether 
  the defendant â€œreceived the property in trust,â€ which he later 
  violated.Â  Jackson, 338 S.C. at 569, 527 S.E.2d at 369 (quoting State 
  v. Shirer, 20 S.C. 392, 408 (1884)).Â  The State, therefore, is required 
  to establish the existence of a trust relationship, and in the absence thereof 
  the defendant is entitled to a directed verdict of acquittal.Â  Id. at 
  569-570, 527 S.E.2d at 370; see State v. LeMaster, 231 S.C. 321, 
  98 S.E.2d 756 (1957).Â Â  
A trust is an arrangement whereby property 
  is transferred to another with the intent that it be administered by the trustee 
  for the benefit of the transferor or a third party.Â  See Jackson, 
  338 S.C. at 570, 527 S.E.2d at 370.Â  As such, it is â€œa fiduciary relationship 
  . . . which arises as a result of a manifestation of an intention to create 
  it.â€Â  Restatement (Second) of Trusts Â§ 2 (1959) (emphasis added).Â  
  In most instances a trust relationship is created by the express intent to do 
  so, either through words or conduct.Â  Id. at Â§ 24.Â  
The instant indictment for breach of 
  trust alleged Jerry Martin â€œentrustedâ€ Parris with $40,340, which Parris later 
  appropriated for his own use.Â  The mere assertion of a trust relationship, however, 
  is not proof of its existenceâ€”the State must present evidence tending to prove 
  the relationship as an element of the crime.Â  Although the indictment failed 
  to specify the nature of the alleged trust, the Stateâ€™s theory of the case, 
  acknowledged in its brief, was that Martin â€œentrustedâ€ Parris with the two checks 
  in exchange for clear title to the mobile home.Â Â  
In support of this theory, the State 
  offered testimony from Jerry Martin that he â€œexpectedâ€ Bank of America to get 
  a clear title to the home when Parris received the checks.Â  The State further 
  relied on Sherry Martinâ€™s testimony that she â€œexpectedâ€ Parrisâ€™s statement at 
  closing was accurateâ€”that â€œhe would have everything doneâ€ in a couple of days 
  so that they could move in by Thanksgiving.Â  According to the State, the Martinsâ€™ 
  testimony reflects a â€œcommon understandingâ€ as to when Parris would deliver 
  the checks to First National.Â  We disagree.Â  In our view, the proffered evidence, 
  ambiguous at best, is insufficient to support a finding of a specific trust 
  agreement.Â  See Jackson, 338 S.C. at 571, 527 S.E.2d at 371 (â€œAbsent 
  the manifest intent to create a trust, there could be no trust or trust relationship 
  to breach.â€); State v. White, 244 S.C. 349, 355, 137 S.E.2d 97, 99 (1964) 
  (â€œâ€˜The [S]tate must prove the exact trust which has been breached . . . .â€™â€) 
  (quoting State v. Cody, 180 S.C. 417, 424, 186 S.E. 165, 167 (1936)); 
  Nickles v. State, 80 S.E.2d 97, 101 (Ga. Ct. App. 1954) (To maintain 
  a conviction for larceny after trust, â€œ[t]here must have been a contract [or] 
  understanding between the defendant and the victim whereby the former received 
  the money from the latter with the distinct agreement and understanding that 
  he would apply the same to a particular use for the benefit of the [victim].â€) 
  (emphasis added).Â  
Although Parris ultimately failed to 
  deliver good title, perhaps warranting a claim for breach of contract, nothing 
  in the record indicates Martin entrusted him with the purchase price for the 
  express purpose of paying off First National to obtain clear title to the trailer.Â  
  To the contrary, the record reveals Martin was unaware title was held by anyone 
  other than Parris until December 6, 1999, and thus could not have intended to 
  create a trust when Parris received the checks on November 18.3 
  We therefore find the State did not prove a trust relationship in this 
  manner.Â  See LeMaster, 231 S.C. at 323-24, 98 S.E.2d at 757 (reversing 
  breach of trust convictions where evidence showed builders informed clients 
  $2,000 was needed to pay for materials, â€œspecifically some $600 owing to one 
  M. D. Martin,â€ and thereafter received the requested funds but failed to pay 
  Martin; the court rejected the Stateâ€™s argument that the $2,000 payment â€œwas 
  impressed with a special trust,â€ finding no evidence of a trust relationship 
  between the builders and clients in part because the Martin bill was not rendered 
  to builders until seven days after they were handed the $2,000 check); Teston 
  v. State, 390 S.E.2d 437, 439 (Ga. Ct. App. 1990) (finding evidence insufficient 
  to establish trust relationship where residential builder allegedly used proceeds 
  of construction loan for purposes other than building specific house; court 
  stated nothing in loan documents or trial testimony â€œprovided that the funds 
  were to be used only forâ€ a particular house).Â  Compare Nickles, 
  80 S.E.2d at 101 (reversing conviction for larceny after trust because there 
  was no evidence defendant was entrusted with money for a particular purpose) 
  with State v. Joy, 851 P.2d 654, 659 (Wash. 1993) (stating embezzlement 
  conviction may be valid when an agreement between the parties restricts the 
  use of funds to a specific purpose, since the party giving the funds has â€œan 
  interest in the . . . application of the money to the purpose for which it was 
  entrusted to defendantâ€).4Â Â  

A trust, however, may arise by implication 
  in the absence of an express common intent if there is a fiduciary relationship 
  between the parties, because â€œ[a] person in a fiduciary relation to another 
  is under a duty to act for the benefit of the other as to matters within the 
  scope of the relation.â€Â  Restatement at Â§ 24.5 
  Accordingly, an implied trust may be proved by evidence tending to show the 
  partiesâ€™ relationship was fiduciary.Â  
The ordinary relationship between unaffiliated 
  parties is not fiduciary.Â  Restatement at Â§ 2.Â  A fiduciary relationship 
  may be created, however, when â€œone reposes special confidence in another so 
  that the latter, in equity and good conscience, is bound to act in good faith 
  and with due regard to the interests of the one reposing the confidence.â€Â  SSI 
  Med. Servs., Inc. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 500, 392 S.E.2d 789, 794 (1990); 
  see Steele v. Victory Sav. Bank, 295 S.C. 290, 293, 368 S.E.2d 
  91, 93 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œA â€˜fiduciary relationshipâ€™ is founded on trust and 
  confidence reposed by one person in the integrity and fidelity of another.â€).Â  
  In general, â€œmere respect for anotherâ€™s judgment or trust in his character is 
  usually not sufficient to establish such a relationship.â€Â  Burwell v. S.C. 
  Natâ€™l Bank, 288 S.C. 34, 41, 340 S.E.2d 786, 790 (1986).Â  Because a fiduciary 
  relationship is based on the trust and confidence reposed by one in the integrity 
  and fidelity of another, the relationship between the parties must be more than 
  casual.Â  Steele, 295 S.C. at 293, 368 S.E.2d at 93.Â  
To establish the existence of a fiduciary 
  relationship, the facts and circumstances must indicate the party reposing trust 
  in another has some foundation for believing the one so entrusted will act not 
  in his own behalf but in the interest of the party so reposing.Â  Burwell, 
  288 S.C. at 41, 340 S.E.2d at 790.Â  Moreover, the evidence must show the entrusted 
  party â€œâ€˜actually accepted or induced the confidence placed in him.â€™â€Â  Brown 
  v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 423, 483 S.E.2d 477, 484 (Ct. App. 1997) (citation 
  omitted).Â  This is because â€œas a general rule, a fiduciary relationship cannot 
  be established by the unilateral action of one party.â€Â  Steele, 295 S.C. 
  at 295, 368 S.E.2d at 94; see Arnold v. Erkmann, 934 S.W. 2d 621, 
  630 (Mo. Ct. App. 1996) (â€œA â€˜fiduciary duty is not created by a unilateral decision 
  to repose trust and confidence; it derives from the conduct or undertaking of 
  the purported fiduciary.â€™â€) (citation omitted); Furrâ€™s Inc. v. United Specialty 
  Adver. Co., 385 S.W.2d 456, 459-60 (Tex. Civ. App. 1964) (finding no confidential 
  relationship existed where buyer failed to present evidence seller was aware 
  of confidence buyer claimed to have reposed in him since a â€œ[c]onfidential relationship 
  is a two[-]way streetâ€).Â  
Although it appears no South Carolina 
  case has addressed the issue, a wealth of foreign case law describes the commercial 
  relationship between a buyer and seller as ordinarily not fiduciary.Â  See, 
  e.g., Comm. on Childrenâ€™s Television, Inc., v. Gen. Foods Corp., 
  673 P.2d 660, 676 (Cal. 1983) (â€œThe relationship of seller to buyer is not one 
  ordinarily vested with fiduciary obligation . . . .Â  A fiduciary, by contrast, 
  assumes duties beyond those of mere fairness and honesty . . . he must undertake 
  to act on behalf of the beneficiary, giving priority to the best interest of 
  the beneficiary.â€); Mabry v. Pelton, 432 S.E.2d 588, 590 (Ga. Ct. App. 
  1993) (â€œâ€˜The vendor and vendee of property are not, by virtue of such fact, 
  placed in a confidential relationship to each other, but on the contrary are 
  presumed to be dealing at armâ€™s length.â€™â€) (citation omitted); Arnold, 
  934 S.W.2d at 629 (â€œA buyer who pays the purchase price to a seller for a specific 
  item or contract right is not â€˜entrustingâ€™ the seller with sums of money for 
  â€˜investmentâ€™ so as to create a fiduciary relationship.â€); Am. Driver Serv., 
  Inc. v. Truck Ins. Exch., 631 N.W.2d 140, 145, 148 (Neb. Ct. App.) (finding 
  no fiduciary duty inhered in armâ€™s-length transaction of buyer and seller despite 
  fact sellers generally have greater expertise and superior bargaining power 
  while buyers typically rely on their representations); Hampton Tree Farms, 
  Inc. v. Jewett, 892 P.2d 683 (Or. 1995) (finding no fiduciary relationship 
  between contracting parties based solely on their agreement to buy and sell 
  logs); Schlumberger Tech. Corp. v. Swanson, 959 S.W.2d 171, 176-77 (Tex. 
  1997) (â€œ[N]ot every relationship involving a high degree of trust and confidence 
  rises to the stature of a fiduciary relationship. . . .Â Â  [T]he fact that the 
  parties to a transaction trust one another will not, in and of itself, establish 
  a finding of a confidential relationship.â€) (internal citations omitted).Â  
The testimonial and documentary evidence 
  offered by the State reveals a quintessential buyer-seller relationship between 
  Marion Parris and Jerry Martin.Â  Nothing in the record indicates Martin reposed 
  a special trust or confidence in Parris such that he had a duty to act only 
  in Martinâ€™s interest as fiduciary.Â  Instead, the evidence is susceptible of 
  only one inferenceâ€”that the receipt of the checks by Parris was part of an armâ€™s-length 
  transaction for the purchase of the mobile home; as such, it cannot serve as 
  the basis of a conviction for breach of trust.Â  See Huff v. State, 
  54 S.E.2d 446, 447 (Ga. Ct. App. 1949) (reversing conviction for larceny after 
  trust where defendant failed to deliver purchased tombstone, court held evidence 
  showed â€œmoney was paid to [defendant] not intrusted to himâ€) (emphasis 
  added); People v. Becker, 111 N.E.2d 491, 498 (Ill. 1953) (reversing 
  conviction of seller because evidence of â€œa transaction which leads only to 
  the debtor[/]creditor relationship will not support a charge of embezzlementâ€); 
  State v. Hardin, 627 S.W.2d 908, 911 (Mo. Ct. App. 1982) (â€œThe breach 
  of a contractual duty does not amount to embezzlement . . . .â€); People v. 
  Wrieden, 87 N.E.2d 440, 442 (N.Y. 1949) (reversing embezzlement conviction 
  where testimonial evidence revealed transaction â€œwas a purchase and sale [which] 
  completely refutes the charge that defendant occupied a position of trustâ€); 
  State v. Carr, 13 P.2d 497, 500 (Wash. 1932) (reversing conviction for 
  embezzlement where dealer accepted $500 down payment but failed either to deliver 
  the piano contracted for or refund buyerâ€™s deposit; court concluded relationship 
  between parties was that of seller and buyer and dealerâ€™s obligation â€œbecame 
  only that of a debtor for damagesâ€).Â  
While this Court does not condone Parrisâ€™s 
  actions, â€œ[t]he object of the breach of trust act . . . was not to make criminal 
  the failure to pay a debt.â€Â  State v. Butler, 21 S.C. 353, 356 (1884).Â  
  There is no question but that Parrisâ€™s failure to deliver good title rightfully 
  would subject him to an action for breach of contract.Â  However, where the seller 
  of an item does not receive the money in question in trust but as payment for 
  the item sold, the failure to use the money in a manner beneficial to the buyer 
  does not constitute a misappropriation of the buyerâ€™s money.Â  To the contrary, 
  the money once given over legally belongs to the seller, and it is elementary 
  that â€œone cannot steal or embezzle his own money so as to render himself criminally 
  liable therefor.â€Â  Carr, 13 P.2d at 500.Â  As the Missouri Court of Appeals 
  has stated:Â  â€œ[A] complaining witness ha[s] no right to invoke criminal process 
  on account of the trouble and expense a civil suit might cause him.Â  â€˜The criminal 
  courts are neither a collection agency nor a forum for the trial of mere disputes 
  over the ownership of property.â€™â€Â  State v. Morris, 699 S.W.2d 33, 36 
  (Mo. Ct. App. 1985) (citation omitted).Â  
The evidence presented in this case fails 
  to show the existence of a fiduciary relationship between Parris and Jerry Martin.Â  
  Instead, it merely evinces a typical buyer-seller relationship between the parties, 
  a relationship not ordinarily fiduciary in nature.Â  Absent the manifest intent 
  to create a trust or evidence establishing the existence of a fiduciary relationship 
  from which one might be implied, the State presented no proof of a trust that 
  was subject to breach.Â  Because the State failed to meet its burden of proving 
  the existence of a trust relationship, the trial court erred in failing to direct 
  a verdict of acquittal on the charge.Â  See LeMaster, 231 S.C. 
  at 324, 98 S.E.2d at 757; Jackson, 338 S.C. at 571-72, 527 S.E.2d at 
  371.Â  
 REVERSED.
 GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.Â  

 
  1 Â Officially 
    known as the â€œManufacturerâ€™s Statement or Certificate of Origin to a Mobile 
    Home.â€Â  

 
  2Â  South Carolina 
    is apparently the only jurisdiction to refer to this offense as breach of 
    trust, as our supreme court has noted:Â  
  
  Breach of trust with fraudulent intention, by that especial 
    designation, is, so far as we are advised, peculiar to this jurisdiction.Â  
    In other states, the crime, as known to us, is called by different names, 
    such as â€œlarceny after trust,â€ â€œlarceny by a bailee,â€ â€œlarceny by false pretenses,â€ 
    and very commonly as â€œembezzlement.â€ . . .Â  The general purpose running through 
    the statutes creating and defining these crimes is, however, the same; to 
    declare as a crime, and usually as one coming within the classification of 
    larceny, acts which were formerly not deemed to be larceny at common law, 
    because of the fact that possession of property had been obtained through 
    the consent of the owner.Â  
  
  State v. McCann, 167 S.C. 393, 400, 166 
    S.E. 411, 414 (1932).Â  Because breach of trust is â€œso similar in its aspects 
    to embezzlement, as the latter crime is defined and regarded in most American 
    jurisdictions,â€ see id., we will utilize the reasoning employed 
    in extra-jurisdictional case law, as did the court in McCann, to support 
    our analysis herein.Â  Â Â 

 
  3Â  Both checks 
    also contained identical endorsement language:Â  
  
  For value received, by endorsement, the 
    payee does warrant good title to and full right to convey a 1999 Legend Mobile 
    Home serial # THL2936ABAL.Â  [And at the] time of such sale and application 
    of certificate of title thereto, payee has shown a lien in favor of Bank of 
    America . . . .Â  
  
  By endorsing the checks, PHS and Jerry Martin recognized 
    Bank of Americaâ€™s interest in the mobile home as well as their right and ability 
    to convey good title.Â  From this evidence it is apparent neither Martin nor 
    Bank of America realized First National had a priority lien on the home; had 
    Bank of America been aware of First Nationalâ€™s interest, it likely would have 
    written the checks as jointly payable to Parris and First National rather 
    than Martin.Â  Although Parris perhaps would be amenable to a charge of selling 
    property encumbered by a lien, see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-1-30 (1991), 
    the evidence supports his innocence of breach of trust.Â  Â Â 

 
  4Â  It is instructive to compare the facts of this case with 
    those where the State properly obtained a conviction for breach of trust based 
    on a specific trust, to wit:Â  State v. Jordan, 255 S.C. 86, 90-91, 
    177 S.E.2d 464, 467 (1970) (upholding stockbrokerâ€™s conviction where he â€œdivert[ed] 
    money received in trust for the purchase of [certain] stockâ€ to personal 
    use rather than applying it â€œin compliance with the trustâ€) (emphasis added); 
    State v. McCann, 167 S.C. 393, 166 S.E. 411 (1932) (affirming conviction 
    where daughter-in-law endorsed and gave check to father-in-law with instructions 
    to â€œpay the doctorâ€™s bill, the drug bill and the funeral bill and bring the 
    rest back,â€ and father-in-law, in addition to paying the debts as instructed 
    also used part of the proceeds to pay his own grocery bill); State v. Barber, 
    90 S.C. 565, 73 S.E. 771 (1912) (sustaining conviction of bail bondsman where 
    clientâ€™s wife entrusted him with $100 for the purpose of paying a commuted 
    fine owed by her husband and he instead appropriated the money for his 
    own use) (emphasis added).Â Â  

 
  5Â  Indeed, some relationships are deemed fiduciary as a matter 
    of law.Â  See, e.g., State v. Ezzard, 40 S.C. 312, 18 S.E. 1025 
    (1894) (principal-agent relationship); StateÂ  v. Scott, 330 S.C. 125, 
    497 S.E.2d 735 (Ct. App. 1998) (employer-employee relationship); State 
    v. Johnson, 314 S.C. 161, 442 S.E.2d 191 (Ct. App. 1994) (foundation-trustee 
    relationship).Â

description: In this criminal appeal, the court ruled that the court had jurisdiction based on an analysis of S.C. Code Ann. section 17-13-40 (Supp. 2001).  Additionally, the court concluded that there was reasonable suspicion to warrant a traffic pursuit.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Oscar Roy Padgett,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Saluda County
William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3608
Heard February 11, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  10, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Haile, 
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Oscar Roy Padgett was convicted of failure to stop for 
  a blue light.Â  The trial court sentenced him to a three-year term of imprisonment.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 31, 2000 at approximately 8:30 p.m., Officer Gerard Grenier of the 
  Ridge Spring Police Department observed a black Mustang parked at the gasoline 
  pumps at Kentâ€™s Corner Gas Station on the corner of Highway 23 and Pecan Grove 
  Road in Ridge Spring.Â  Officer Grenier recognized the vehicle as the same one 
  he had stopped two months earlier for a license tag violation.Â  Padgett was 
  driving the vehicle at the time of the prior stop and had explained to Officer 
  Grenier that he had purchased it only a few days earlier.
Officer Grenier testified that, on the night in question, he saw 
  Padgett get into the vehicle and decided to follow Padgett to ascertain whether 
  he had obtained proper tags for the car.Â  As he â€œsquared offâ€ behind the Mustang 
  on Highway 23, Officer Grenier noticed that no license tags were affixed to 
  the vehicle and, therefore, activated his patrol carâ€™s blue lights.Â  He stated 
  the driver of the vehicle did not stop in response to the blue lights, but rather 
  drove slowly for a time, turned onto Trojan Road, accelerated the vehicle, and 
  crossed over Highway 1 into Aiken.Â  According to Officer Grenier, he pursued 
  Padgett with his siren and blue lights on for about three-fourths of a mile 
  outside of Ridge Spring, then terminated the pursuit.Â  He returned to Kentâ€™s 
  Corner and questioned the store manager regarding the identity of the person 
  driving the black Mustang.Â  The manager informed Officer Grenier that the driver 
  was Oscar Padgett.Â  Thereafter, Officer Grenier obtained a warrant for Padgettâ€™s 
  arrest.
Officer Leroy Smith, who was on patrol with Grenier the night of the pursuit, 
  verified Officer Grenierâ€™s account of the events.Â  In particular, Officer 
  Smith confirmed that Officer Grenier turned on the patrol carâ€™s blue lights 
  before Padgett turned onto Trojan Road and, thus, before he left the Ridge Spring 
  city limits.
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, Padgett moved for a directed 
  verdict of acquittal based generally on lack of sufficient evidence.Â  The trial 
  court denied the motion.
 Padgett declared he was not in Ridge Spring on 
  the night of October 31, 2000.Â  He further asserted the transmission on his 
  black Mustang was malfunctioning at the time and had been parked in his back 
  yard.
At the close of evidence, Padgett renewed his motion for a directed 
  verdict.Â  The trial court again denied the motion.Â  The jury returned 
  a guilty verdict.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court must view 
  the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Walker, 
  349 S.C. 49, 562 S.E.2d 313 (2002); State v. Morgan, Â Â Â S.C.Â Â  
  , 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When ruling on a motion for a directed 
  verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of 
  evidence, not its weight. State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 
  (2002); State v. McLauren, 349 S.C. 488, 563 S.E.2d 346 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce 
  evidence of the offense charged.Â  State v. McKnight, Op. No. 25585 (S.C. 
  Sup. Ct. filed Jan. 27, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 3 at 42); State v. 
  McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 544 S.E.2d 30 (2001).Â  However, if there is any direct 
  evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove 
  the guilt of the accused, this Court must find the case was properly submitted 
  to the jury.Â  State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 572 S.E.2d 267 (2002); State 
  v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 562 S.E.2d 320 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Jurisdiction 
  of Law Enforcement Officer
Padgett asserts the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict 
  of acquittal on the charge of failure to stop for a blue light due to the lack 
  of jurisdiction on the part of the pursuing officer.Â  Padgett claims the officer 
  did not turn on his blue lights until he was â€œoutside the corporate limits according 
  to the city map.â€
Â The polestar of the factual inquiry in this case is a determination 
  of when the law enforcement activity began and whether it originated in the 
  town limits.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-40 (Supp. 2001) provides, in relevant part:

Law enforcement officer jurisdiction when in pursuit of offender; authority, 
  rights, privileges, and immunities extended.
  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (A) When the police authorities of a town or city 
  are in pursuit of an offender for a violation of a municipal ordinance or statute 
  of this State committed within the corporate limits, the authorities may arrest 
  the offender, with or without a warrant, at a place within the corporate limits, 
  at a place within the county in which the town or city is located, or at a place 
  within a radius of three miles of the corporate limits.
  

Padgett correctly notes that section 17-13-40(A), by its terms, operates 
  to limit the jurisdictional authority of town and city police officers to effectuate 
  arrests.Â  However, the mere fact that there existed some question as to whether 
  the officers in the instant case were operating outside of their jurisdictional 
  limitations does not automatically give rise to the propriety of a directed 
  verdict on the issue.Â  To the contrary, the facts and circumstances attendant 
  to this case present quintessential factual issues regarding the exercise of 
  the statutory grant of jurisdiction.
The officersâ€™ testimony that they initiated the attempted traffic stop inside 
  the Ridge Spring city limits, standing alone, constituted sufficient evidence 
  to defeat Padgettâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the ground the officers 
  lacked jurisdiction to make the stop.Â  Cf. State v. McAteer, 340 
  S.C. 644, 646, 532 S.E.2d 865, 866 (2000) (concluding that â€œ[s]ince the officer 
  was outside the municipalityâ€™s city limits when he first observed petitioner, 
  he had no police authority to detain him.â€).Â  In ruling on the motion for a 
  directed verdict, the trial judge properly limited his inquiry to the existence 
  or nonexistence of evidence tending to establish the officers operated within 
  the confines of section 17-13-40(A), not the weight of that evidence.Â  See 
  State v. Morgan, 282 S.C. 409, 319 S.E.2d 335 (1984).Â  The trial court 
  did not err in denying Padgettâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.
II.Â  Reasonable Suspicion 
  to Warrant Traffic Pursuit
Padgett contends the trial court erred in failing to grant his motion 
  for a directed verdict on the charge of failure to stop for a blue light due 
  to the lack of reasonable suspicion to warrant the traffic pursuit.Â  We disagree.
The dissenting opinion in State v. Jihad, 342 S.C. 138, 536 
  S.E.2d 79 (Ct. App. 2000) (Anderson, J., dissenting), majority opinion revâ€™d 
  on other grounds, 347 S.C. 12, 553 S.E.2d 249 (2001), articulated:

A police officer may conduct a constitutionally valid traffic stop when the 
  officer has a reasonable suspicion that either the vehicle or an occupant is 
  subject to seizure for violation of the law.Â  See Delaware v. Prouse, 
  440 U.S. 648, 99 S.Ct. 1391, 59 L.Ed.2d 660 (1979).Â  As long as an officer reasonably 
  suspects the driver is violating â€œany one of the multitude of applicable traffic 
  and equipment regulations,â€ the police officer may legally stop the vehicle.Â  
  Id. at 661, 99 S.Ct. at 1400, 59 L.Ed.2d at 672.Â Â  Reasonable suspicion 
  is a lesser standard than probable cause and allows an officer to effectuate 
  a stop when there is some objective manifestation of criminal activity involving 
  the person stopped.Â  See United States v. Sokolow, 490 U.S. 1, 
  109 S.Ct. 1581, 104 L.Ed.2d 1 (1989).Â  Reasonable suspicion exists when an officer 
  can identify specific facts that, when taken together with rational inferences 
  from those facts, would warrant a person of reasonable caution in the belief 
  that the detainee has committed (or is committing) a crime.Â  Terry v. Ohio, 
  392 U.S. 1, 88 S.Ct. 1868, 20 L.Ed.2d 889 (1968).Â  The propriety of a stop must 
  be viewed in light of the totality of the surrounding circumstances.Â  See 
  United States v. Cortez, 449 U.S. 411, 101 S.Ct. 690, 66 L.Ed.2d 621 
  (1981).
No further inquiry beyond the requirement of reasonable suspicion 
  is necessary or warranted.Â  State v. Carlson, 102 Ohio App. 3d 585, 657 
  N.E.2d 591 (1995).Â  Thus, if the specific and articulable facts available to 
  an officer indicate a motorist may be committing a criminal act, which includes 
  the violation of a traffic law, the officer is justified in making the stop.Â  
  Id. Similarly, the United States Supreme Court has concluded an officerâ€™s 
  subjective motive does not invalidate behavior that is objectively justified 
  under the Fourth Amendment.Â  See Whren v. United States, 517 U.S. 
  806, 116 S.Ct. 1769, 135 L.Ed.2d 89 (1996) (police officer may stop driver for 
  any observed traffic offense even if officerâ€™s motivation for making stop is 
  unrelated to observed traffic offense).Â  To satisfy the reasonable suspicion 
  standard, the State is not required to prove the suspected motor vehicle violation 
  occurred.Â  State v. Williamson, 138 N.J. 302, 650 A.2d 348 (1994); see 
  also Marben v. State of Minnesota, Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 294 N.W.2d 
  697 (Minn. 1980) (an actual traffic violation need not be detectable; all that 
  is required is that the stop be not the product of mere whim, caprice, or idle 
  curiosity).

Jihad, 342 S.C. at 147-48, 536 S.E.2d at 83-84.
Pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 56-3-1240 (Supp. 2002), â€œ[i]t is unlawful 
  to operate or drive a motor vehicle with the license plate missing and a person 
  who is convicted for violating this section must be punished as provided by 
  Section 56-3-2520.â€Â  Officer Grenier testified he noticed that the vehicle he 
  pursued on October 31, 2000 did not have a license tag affixed to it.Â  Because 
  the mere act of driving a vehicle without a license plate is a chargeable offense, 
  Officer Grenierâ€™s observation that the plate was missing from the vehicle constituted 
  reasonable suspicion to initiate the traffic stop.Â  The fact that Officer Grenier 
  was prompted to check for the missing license plate by his recollection of a 
  prior stop of the same vehicle does not negate the existence of reasonable suspicion 
  to initiate the stop when he actually observed Padgett committing a traffic 
  offense on the night in question.Â  Concomitantly, we find the case was properly 
  submitted to the jury.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, for the foregoing reasons, Padgettâ€™s conviction is
 AFFIRMED.
 CONNOR and HUFF, JJ., concur.

description: In this criminal appeal, the court ruled that Cuccia's double jeopardy rights were not violated when his license was suspended under S.C. Code Ann. section 56-1-286(A) (Supp. 1998) and he was subsequently tried under S.C. Code Ann. section 56-5-2930 (Supp. 1999) for D.U.I.
