THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Curtis Frank Cuccia,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3609
Submitted February 10, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  March 10, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Stephen D. Schusterman, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
        Christopher Edward Anthony Barton, of Rock Hill, for
        Respondent.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Curtis Cuccia was charged with driving under the influence 
  (DUI), open container, possession of beer by a person under twenty-one years 
  old, and speeding.Â  His driverâ€™s license was suspended due to registering a 
  blood-alcohol level of two one-hundredths of one percent (.02%) or more and 
  being under twenty-one years old.Â  He pled guilty to the open container charge, 
  and the possession of beer and speeding charges were nolle prossed.Â  
  Cuccia was subsequently convicted of DUI.Â  Cuccia appeals his DUI conviction 
  and sentence.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Municipal Judge Modlaâ€™s Return to Appeal details the testimony presented by 
  the arresting officer, Officer Biggers.Â  Officer Biggers testified that he stopped 
  Cuccia for speeding.Â  When Cuccia exited his vehicle, Officer Biggers smelled 
  alcohol and noticed Cuccia was very unsteady on his feet.Â  Cuccia failed four 
  field sobriety tests.Â  Officer Biggers averred that he observed an open beer 
  bottle on the floorboard.Â  At the time of Cucciaâ€™s arrest, he was nineteen years 
  old.Â Â  
Officer Pruett performed a Breathalyzer test.Â  The test result indicated Cucciaâ€™s 
  alcohol concentration was twenty-one one-hundredths of one percent (.21%), well 
  above the two one-hundredths of one percent (.02%) limit for suspending his 
  license under S.C. Code Ann. section 56-1-286(A) (Supp. 2002).Â  The level is 
  also above ten one-hundredths of one percent (.10%) or more, where it may be 
  inferred that the person was under the influence of alcohol under S.C. Code 
  Ann. section 56-5-2950(b)(3) (Supp. 2002).
After the test was performed, a Notice of Suspension form was completed in 
  which two boxes were checked as the reason for the suspension of Cucciaâ€™s license.Â  
  The first box was for registering an alcohol concentration of .02% or more while 
  under the age of twenty-one, and the second checked box was for registering 
  an alcohol concentration of .15% or more.Â  Officer Biggers elected to pursue 
  the suspension as a result of Cucciaâ€™s alcohol concentration of .02% or greater 
  and the fact he was under the age of twenty-one. 
Cuccia pled guilty to the open container charge, and the possession of beer 
  and speeding charges were nolle prossed.Â  At the trial on the 
  DUI charge, Cuccia moved to dismiss the charge contending that it would be double 
  jeopardy for him to have his license revoked and to face the charge of DUI.Â  
  The motion to dismiss was denied on the grounds that Cuccia was arrested for 
  DUI, but his license was suspended under an administrative or civil sanction 
  and was not a criminal penalty barring subsequent prosecution for DUI.Â  Cuccia 
  was subsequently convicted of DUI and sentenced to thirty days incarceration 
  or a fine of $559.00.
LAW/ANALYSIS 
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Civil Sanction
Cuccia maintains his protection from double jeopardy 
  was violated when his license was suspended under S.C. Code Ann. section 56-1-286(A) 
  (Supp. 1998) and he was subsequently tried under S.C. Code Ann. section 56-5-2930 
  (Supp. 1999) for DUI.Â  We disagree.
Section 56-1-286(A) (Supp. 2002) states:

In addition to any other penalty imposed by law unless otherwise prohibited 
  in this section, including additional driver's license suspensions, the Department 
  of Public Safety must suspend the driver's license, permit, or nonresident operating 
  privilege of, or deny the issuance of a license or permit to a person under 
  the age of twenty-one who drives a motor vehicle and has an alcohol concentration 
  of two one-hundredths of one percent or more. The department shall not suspend 
  a person's privilege to drive under this section if the person's privilege to 
  drive has been suspended for a violation of Section 20-7-8920, 20-7-8925, or 
  56-5-2930 arising from the same incident.

Both the United States Constitution and the South 
  Carolina Constitution protect against double jeopardy.Â  The United States Constitution, 
  which is applicable to South Carolina through the Fourteenth Amendment, provides: 
  â€œ[N]or shall any person be subject for the same offence to be twice put in jeopardy 
  of life or limb . . . .â€Â  U.S. Const. Amend. V.Â  The South Carolina Constitution 
  states: â€œNo person shall be subject for the same offense to be twice put in 
  jeopardy of life or liberty . . . .â€Â  S.C. Const. Art. I, Â§ 12.Â  The â€œguarantee 
  [against double jeopardy] has been said to consist of three separate constitutional 
  protections. It protects against a second prosecution for the same offense after 
  acquittal. It protects against a second prosecution for the same offense after 
  conviction. And it protects against multiple punishments for the same offense.â€Â  
  North Carolina v. Pearce, 395 U.S. 711, 717, 89 S. Ct. 2072, 2076, 23 
  L. Ed. 2d 656, 664-65 (1969) (overruled on other grounds by Alabama v. Smith, 
  490 U.S. 794, 109 S.Ct. 2201, 104 L.Ed.2d 865 (1989)); accord Schiro 
  v. Farley, 510 U.S. 222, 114 S.Ct. 783, 127 L.Ed.2d 47 (1994); Justices 
  of Boston Mun. Ct. v. Lydon, 466 U.S. 294, 104 S.Ct. 1805, 80 L.Ed.2d 311 
  (1984); United States. v. DiFrancesco, 449 U.S. 117, 101 S.Ct. 426, 66 
  L.Ed.2d 328 (1980); Brown v. Ohio, 432 U.S. 161, 97 S.Ct. 2221, 53 L.Ed.2d 
  187 (1977); United States v. Watson, 420 U.S. 332, 95 S.Ct. 1013, 43 
  L.Ed.2d 232 (1975); Stevenson v. State, 335 S.C. 193, 198, 516 S.E.2d 
  434, 436 (1999); McMullin v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue & Taxation, 
  321 S.C. 475, 478, 469 S.E.2d 600, 602 (1996); State v. Owens, 309 S.C. 
  402, 405, 424 S.E.2d 473, 475 (1992); see also In re Matthews, 
  345 S.C. 638, 648, 550 S.E.2d 311, 316 (2001) (â€œThe Double Jeopardy Clause protects 
  against multiple punishments for the same offense.â€).

If there is anything settled in the jurisprudence of England 
  and America, it is that no man can be twice lawfully punished for the same offence. 
  And though there have been nice questions in the application of this rule to 
  cases in which the act charged was such as to come within the definition of 
  more than one statutory offence, or to bring the party within the jurisdiction 
  of more than one court, there has never been any doubt of its entire and complete 
  protection of the party when a second punishment is proposed in the same court, 
  on the same facts, for the same statutory offence.Â  

Ex Parte Lange, 85 U.S. 163, 168, 21 L. Ed. 872 (1873).Â  However, the 
  Double Jeopardy Clause does not prohibit the imposition of all additional sanctions 
  that could, â€œin common parlance,â€ be described as punishment.Â  Hudson v. 
  United States, 522 U.S. 93, 98-99, 118 S.Ct. 488, 493, 139 L.Ed.2d 450 (1997).Â Â  
  â€œThe Clause protects only against the imposition of multiple criminal 
  punishments for the same offense.â€Â  Id. at 99, 118 S.Ct. at 493, 139 
  L.Ed.2d at 458 (emphasis in original). Â Nevertheless, the Clause may prevent 
  the government from subjecting a defendant to both a criminal punishment and 
  a civil sanction.Â  State v. Price, 333 S.C. 267, 270, 510 S.E.2d 215, 
  217 (1998).Â  The Double Jeopardy Clause is not automatically violated by the 
  mere fact that a civil penalty has some deterrent effect.Â  Id. at 270-71, 
  510 S.E.2d at 218.Â  To determine whether a penalty is criminal or civil, a court 
  must look to the face of the statute and then determine if the statutory scheme 
  is so punitive in purpose or effect as to transform what was intended as a civil 
  sanction into a criminal penalty.Â  Id. at 271, 510 S.E.2d at 218.

Whether a particular punishment is criminal or civil 
  is, at least initially, a matter of statutory construction.Â  A court must first 
  ask whether the legislature, â€œin establishing the penalizing mechanism, indicated 
  either expressly or impliedly a preference for one label or the other.â€Â  Even 
  in those cases where the legislature â€œhas indicated an intention to establish 
  a civil penalty, we have inquired further whether the statutory scheme was so 
  punitive either in purpose or effect,â€ as to â€œtransfor[m] what was clearly intended 
  as a civil remedy into a criminal penalty.

Hudson, 522 U.S. at 99, 118 S.Ct. at 493, 139 L.Ed.2d 
  at 459 (internal citations omitted); see also In re Matthews, 
  345 S.C. 638, 648, 550 S.E.2d 311, 316 (2001) (â€œAs the United States Supreme 
  Court recently reiterated, the determination whether a statute is civil or criminal 
  is primarily a question of statutory construction, which must begin by reference 
  to the actâ€™s text and legislative history.â€).Â  â€œOnly the clearest proof will 
  suffice to override legislative intent and transform what has been denominated 
  as a civil remedy into a criminal penalty.â€Â  Price, 333 S.C. at 271, 
  510 S.E.2d at 218; accord In re Matthews, 345 S.C. at 648, 550 
  S.E.2d at 316.Â  The Hudson court enunciated seven factors for determining 
  if a statute constitutes a criminal penalty:

(1) [w]hether the sanction involves an affirmative disability or restraint; 
  (2) whether it has historically been regarded as a punishment; (3) whether it 
  comes into play only on a finding of scienter; (4) whether its operation will 
  promote the traditional aims of punishment-retribution and deterrence; (5) whether 
  the behavior to which it applies is already a crime; (6) whether an alternative 
  purpose to which it may rationally be connected is assignable for it; and (7) 
  whether it appears excessive in relation to the alternative purpose assigned.

Hudson 522 U.S. at 99-100, 118 S.Ct. at 493, 139 L.Ed.2d 
  at 459.
Section 56-1-286 allows for the suspension of a driverâ€™s license where the 
  person is under the age of twenty-one and registers a blood alcohol concentration 
  of two one-hundredths of one percent (.02%) or more. Â 
The South Carolina Supreme Court, in State v. Price, 333 S.C. 267, 510 
  S.E.2d 215 (1998), undertook an exhaustive examination of the administrative 
  revocation of a driverâ€™s license for the refusal to submit to a Breathalyzer 
  exam and determined that it is not a criminal penalty. 
  [2] Â  Id. at 274, 510 S.E.2d at 219.Â  The court found the following 
  factors determinative in reaching its conclusion:Â  (1) the authority to impose 
  the suspension is vested in an administrative agency [the Department of Public 
  Safety]; (2) the ability to operate a motor vehicle on the highways is a privilege, 
  rather than a right; (3) â€œthe purpose of the revocation is to protect the public 
  and not to punish the licensee;â€ [3] 
   (4) â€œthe sanctions here do not involve an â€˜affirmative disability or restraintâ€™ 
  as that term is normally understood;â€ (5) the sanction â€œcome[s] into play only 
  upon a finding of scienter, i.e., refusal to submit to testing, no one of these 
  factors alone is dispositive,â€ (6)â€œalthough the sanction of license revocation 
  may serve the goals of punishment (i.e., deterrence and retribution), the primary 
  goal . . . is to protect the public;â€ and (7) â€œnearly every other court which 
  has addressed the issue finds no double jeopardy problem is posed by the administrative 
  suspension of a driver's license following a drunk driving arrest or refusal 
  to submit to chemical testing.â€Â  Id. at 272-74, 510 S.E.2d at 218-19.
We find no reason why the rationale enounced in Price is not equally 
  efficacious in an analysis of a suspension under section 56-1-286.Â  The section 
  makes clear that the suspension is in addition to any other penalties which 
  are imposed by law.Â  It is clearly not intended to be the sole criminal penalty 
  for a person under the age of twenty-one who drives while under the influence 
  of alcohol.Â  The statute gives authority to the Department of Public Safety 
  to handle the suspension.Â  As in Price, the mere fact that the conduct 
  for which the sanction is imposed is also criminal is insufficient to render 
  the sanction criminally punitive.Â  Id. atÂ  273-74, 510 S.E.2d at 219.Â  

Accordingly, we find the revocation of a driverâ€™s 
  license, where a driver under the age of twenty-one registers a blood alcohol 
  concentration of two one-hundredths of one percent (.02%), is a civil sanction 
  which has not been transformed into a criminal punishment.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Same Elements Test
Under traditional double jeopardy analysis, multiple punishment is not prohibited 
  where each offense calls for proof of a fact that the other does not.Â  State 
  v. Owens, 309 S.C. 402, 405, 424 S.E.2d 473, 475 (1992).Â  The United States 
  Supreme Court and the South Carolina Supreme Court have determined that in the 
  context of criminal penalties, the Blockburger v. United States, 284 
  U.S. 299, 52 S. Ct. 180, 76 L. Ed. 306 (1932) â€œsame elementsâ€ test is the sole 
  test of double jeopardy in successive prosecutions and multiple punishment cases.Â  
  See United States v. Dixon, 509 U.S. 688, 113 S. Ct. 2849, 125 
  L. Ed. 2d 556 (1993); State v. Easler, 327 S.C. 121, 489 S.E.2d 617 (1997) 
  (â€œ[W]e decline to extend broader protection under our state constitution than 
  that afforded under the federal constitution.â€).Â  As the South Carolina Supreme 
  Court noted in Price, â€œif a sanction is determined to be civil in nature 
  and has not been transformed into a criminal penalty, then the double jeopardy 
  clause is not implicated and there is simply no need to conduct a Blockburger 
  analysis.â€Â  Price, 333 S.C. at 271, n.4, 510 S.E.2d at 218, n.4.Â Â  
However, once a sanction is found to be a criminal penalty, the Blockburger 
  â€œsame elementsâ€ test would apply.Â  Blockburger insists upon a comparison 
  of the elements of the two offenses to determine if â€œeach provision requires 
  proof of an additional fact which the other does not.â€Â  Blockburger, 
  284 U.S. at 304.Â  A mere overlap in proof does not constitute a double jeopardy 
  violation.Â  State v. Owens, 309 S.C. 402, 405, 424 S.E.2d 473, 475 (1992).
Section 56-1-286 allows for the suspension of the driverâ€™s license of (1) a 
  person, (2) under the age of twenty-one, (3) who drives, (4) a motor vehicle, 
  and (5) has a blood alcohol concentration of two one-hundredths of one percent 
  or more.Â  Section 56-5-2930 makes it unlawful for (1) a person, (2) to drive, 
  (3) a motor vehicle, (4) while under the influence of alcohol, and (5) to the 
  extent that the personâ€™s faculties to drive are materially and appreciably impaired.
Section 56-5-2930 (Supp. 2002) provides:

It is unlawful for a person to drive a motor vehicle within this State while:

  (1) under the influence of alcohol to the extent that the person's faculties 
  to drive are materially and appreciably impaired;
  (2) under the influence of any other drug or a combination of other drugs or 
  substances which cause impairment to the extent that the person's faculties 
  to drive are materially and appreciably impaired; or
(3) under the combined influence of alcohol and any other drug or drugs or substances 
  which cause impairment to the extent that the person's faculties to drive are 
  materially and appreciably impaired.

Even if we were to find the suspension of Cucciaâ€™s license under section 56-1-286 
  was a criminal penalty, we hold, pursuant to the Blockburger â€œsame elementsâ€ 
  test, that a subsequent prosecution for DUI does not violate Cucciaâ€™s double 
  jeopardy protections.Â  The two provisions do not necessitate proof of identical 
  elements.Â  One needs an age under twenty-one with a blood alcohol of above .02%, 
  while the other is for any age driver whose faculties to drive are â€œmaterially 
  and appreciably impaired.â€Â  Violation of one provision does not result in an 
  automatic finding of a violation of the other provision.Â  Accordingly, pursuant 
  to the Blockburger â€œsame elementsâ€ test, suspending Cucciaâ€™s license 
  under section 56-1-286 does not prohibit a subsequent prosecution under section 
  56-5-2930 for DUI, as the provisions require proof of different facts.
CONCLUSION
We find the administrative suspension of Cucciaâ€™s 
  driverâ€™s license for driving with a blood alcohol level of two one-hundredths 
  of one percent or more while under the age of twenty-one is a civil sanction 
  and not a criminal penalty.Â  Additionally, we conclude even if it were transformed 
  into a criminal penalty, the elements for suspension of the license under section 
  56-1-286 are not the same as the elements for prosecuting a DUI under section 
  56-5-2930.Â  Indubitably, Cuccia was properly prosecuted for DUI, subsequent 
  to the revocation of his driverâ€™s license, without violation of the Double Jeopardy 
  Clause.
AFFIRMED.
CONNOR and HUFF, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  The Court scrutinized former S.C. Code Ann. section 
    56-5-2950 (Supp. 1997), which read, â€œIf a person under arrest refuses, upon 
    the request of a law enforcement officer, to submit to chemical tests as provided 
    in subsection (a) of this section, . . . the department, . . . shall suspend 
    his license or permit to drive, or any nonresident operating privilege for 
    a period of ninety days.â€Â  The section is now codified at S.C. Code Ann. section 
    56-5-2951 (A) (Supp. 2001).Â  

 
   [3]  Price, 333 S.C. at 272, 510 S.E.2d at 218 
    (quoting Parker v. State Highway Department, 224 S.C. 263, 271, 78 
    S.E.2d 382, 386 (1953)).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  appellate court lacks the opportunity for direct observation of witnesses, it 
  should accord great deference to the Family Courtâ€™s findings where matters of 
  credibility are involved); Terwilliger v. Terwilliger, 298 S.C. 144, 
  378 S.E.2d 609 (Ct. App. 1989) (holding the resolution of questions regarding 
  credibility and the weight given to testimony is a function of the Family Court 
  judge who heard the testimony).Â  Because the appellate court lacks the opportunity 
  for direct observation of witnesses, it should accord great deference to trial 
  court findings where matters of credibility are involved.Â  Shirley v. Shirley, 
  342 S.C. 324, 536 S.E.2d 427 (Ct. App. 2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Credit Card Debt
Husband argues the Family Court erred in identifying $12,332 in credit card 
  charges as marital debt subject to equitable division, and in allocating the 
  debt to him, inasmuch as Wife incurred the debt after this action was commenced.Â  
  I agree the debt should not have been allocated to Husband.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2002) provides in pertinent part:
In making apportionment, the court must give weight 
  in such proportion as it finds appropriate to all of the following factors:

. . . .
(13)Â  liens and any other encumbrances upon the marital property, which themselves 
  must be equitably divided, or upon the separate property of either of the parties, 
  and any other existing debts incurred by the parties or either of them during 
  the course of the marriage . . . .

Debts incurred for marital purposes are subject to equitable distribution.Â  
  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 545 S.E.2d 531 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Section 
  20-7-472 creates a rebuttable presumption that a debt of either spouse incurred 
  prior to marital litigation is a marital debt, and must be factored into 
  the totality of equitable apportionment.Â  Hickum v. Hickum, 320 S.C. 
  97, 463 S.E.2d 321 (Ct. App. 1995).
â€œMarital debtâ€ has been defined as debt incurred for the joint benefit of the 
  parties regardless of whether the parties are legally jointly liable for the 
  debt or whether one party is legally individually liable.Â  Thomas v. Thomas, 
  346 S.C. 20, 550 S.E.2d 580 (Ct. App. 2001), cert. granted, Jan. 24, 
  2002; Hardy v. Hardy, 311 S.C. 433, 429 S.E.2d 811 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
  In equitably dividing a marital estate, the Family Court is to consider the 
  net estate, and must apportion marital debt in conjunction with the apportionment 
  of assets.Â  Hardy, 311 S.C. at 437, 429 S.E.2d at 813; see also 
  Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 486 S.E.2d 516 (Ct. App. 1997) (marital 
  debt is a factor to be considered in making the equitable apportionment).Â  Marital 
  debt, like marital property, must be specifically identified and apportioned 
  in equitable distribution.Â  Smith, 327 S.C. at 457, 486 S.E.2d at 520 
  (section 20-7-472 implicitly requires that marital debt, like marital property, 
  be specifically identified and apportioned in the equitable distribution); Frank 
  v. Frank, 311 S.C. 454, 429 S.E.2d 823 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  The same rules 
  of fairness and equity which apply to the equitable division of marital property 
  also apply to the division of marital debts.Â  Hardy, 311 S.C. at 437, 
  429 S.E.2d at 813-14.
The burden of proving a spouseâ€™s debt as nonmarital rests upon the party who 
  makes such an assertion.Â  Hickum, 320 S.C. at 103, 463 S.E.2d at 324.Â  
  If the trial judge finds that a spouseâ€™s debt was not made for marital purposes, 
  it need not be factored into the courtâ€™s equitable apportionment of the marital 
  estate, and the trial judge may require payment by the spouse who created the 
  debt for nonmarital purposes.Â  Id.
Even where a spouse individually incurs debt after a marital separation 
  but before a divorce decree is entered, the debt should be apportioned in accordance 
  with the principles of equitable distribution where there is a showing that 
  the debt was incurred for the joint benefit of both parties.Â  SeeÂ  Peirson 
  v. Calhoun, 308 S.C. 246, 417 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 1992); see also 
  Allen v. Allen, 287 S.C. 501, 339 S.E.2d 872 (Ct. App. 1986) (finding 
  that while it is proper to consider marital debts in making an equitable distribution 
  of marital assets, it is also incumbent upon the court which apportions such 
  debts to ensure the debts were incurred for the joint benefit of the parties 
  during the marriage).
In the instant case, Wife has made no showing, and I am unable to 
  discern from the record on appeal, that the credit card debts she incurred during 
  the partiesâ€™ separation were incurred for any purpose inuring to the benefit 
  of Husband.Â  Rather, Wife testified she used her credit card to pay part of 
  a college tuition bill for one of the partiesâ€™ children and to buy medication, 
  food, and clothing.Â  While these were perhaps legitimate expenses, the resulting 
  credit card debt was not, in my view, incurred for the joint benefit of the 
  parties within the meaning of the governing statute and applicable case law.Â  
  Moreover, these credit card charges were incurred by Wife subsequent 
  to the filing of marital litigation.Â  The court erred in considering the credit 
  card charges as marital debt subject to equitable apportionment.Â  Concomitantly, 
  I agree with the majorityâ€™s decision to reverse the portion of the Family Courtâ€™s 
  order allocating the credit card debt to Husband.
II.Â  Marital Home
Husband asserts the Family Court erred in awarding Wife ownership 
  of the marital home as part of her share in the marital estate.Â  I disagree.
The Family Court is given broad jurisdiction in the equitable distribution 
  of marital property.Â  Murphy v. Murphy, 319 S.C. 324, 461 S.E.2d 39 (1995); 
  see also Greene v. Greene 351 S.C. 329, 569 S.E.2d 393 (Ct. App. 
  2002) (holding Family Court has wide discretion in determining how marital property 
  is to be distributed).Â  The court may use any reasonable means to divide the 
  property equitably.Â  Bowyer v. Sohn, 290 S.C. 249, 349 S.E.2d 403 (1986); 
  Belton v. Belton, 325 S.C. 456, 481 S.E.2d 174 (Ct. App. 1997); see 
  also Coxe v. Coxe, 294 S.C. 291, 363 S.E.2d 906 (Ct. App. 1987) (stating 
  Family Court judges are given broad jurisdiction in equitable distribution of 
  marital property and trial judge may use any reasonable means to divide estate 
  equitably). Â The apportionment of marital property is within the Family Court 
  judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002); Peirson 
  v. Calhoun, 308 S.C. 246, 417 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 1992).
In order to effect an equitable apportionment, the Family Court may require 
  the sale of marital property and a division of the proceeds.Â  Donahue v. 
  Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 384 S.E.2d 741 (1989); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-476 
  (Supp. 2002) (providing that â€œ[t]he court in making an equitable apportionment 
  may order the public or private sale of all or any portion of the marital property 
  upon terms it determines.â€).Â  The court, however, should first attempt an â€œin-kindâ€ 
  distribution of the marital assets.Â  Donahue, 299 S.C. at 360, 384 S.E.2d 
  at 745; Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 368 S.E.2d 901 (1988).Â  
  A Family Court may grant a spouse title to the marital home as part of the equitable 
  distribution.Â  Donahue, 299 S.C. at 360, 384 S.E.2d at 745.Â  Pursuant 
  to Â§ 20-7-472(10) of the South Carolina Code, the court, in making apportionment, 
  â€œmust give weight in such proportion as it finds appropriate to all of the following 
  factors: . . . (10) the desirability of awarding the family home as part of 
  equitable distribution.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(10) (Supp. 2002).
Section 20-7-472 lists fifteen factors for the Family Court to consider 
  when making an equitable apportionment of the marital estate.Â  Bowers, 
  349 S.C. at 97, 561 S.E.2d at 616.Â  The statute vests the Family Court with 
  the discretion to decide what weight should be assigned to the various factors.Â  
  Id.Â  On review, this Court looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment, 
  and if the result is equitable, that this Court might have weighed specific 
  factors differently than the Family Court is irrelevant.Â  Id.
In deciding to award Wife the marital home in partial realization 
  of her share in the marital estate, the Family Court expressly weighed: the 
  length of time the parties and their children resided in the home during the 
  marriage; Wifeâ€™s desire to remain in the home; and the central role the home 
  played in the partiesâ€™ lifestyles during the marriage.Â  As well, the court considered 
  the fact that Wifeâ€™s deceased father personally performed much of the woodwork 
  on the home during the process of renovation.Â  Pointedly, the court specifically 
  noted that it â€œcould not award the marital home to the Wife no matter how desirable 
  unless it were a part of the fifty percent (50%) of the marital estate to which 
  she is entitled.â€
Under these facts and circumstances, there is no error or abuse of 
  discretion in the Family Courtâ€™s decision to award Wife the marital home instead 
  of ordering its sale.Â  I am particularly convinced of the propriety of the courtâ€™s 
  decision in this regard in light of Husbandâ€™s vastly superior income and ability 
  to purchase a home without the necessity of divesting Wife of the marital home.
III.Â  Tax 
  Ramifications
Husband claims 
  the Family Court erred in failing to consider the tax consequences in the division 
  of the marital estate.Â  I disagree.
In Ellerbe 
  v. Ellerbe, 323 S.C. 283, 473 S.E.2d 881 (Ct. App. 1996), the Court of Appeals 
  analyzed tax issues in connection with equitable apportionment and stated:

South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(11) (Supp. 1995) requires 
  the family court to consider the tax consequences to each party resulting from 
  equitable apportionment.Â  However, if the apportionment order does not contemplate 
  the liquidation or sale of an asset, then it is an abuse of discretion for the 
  court to consider the tax consequences from a supposed sale or liquidation.Â  
  See Graham v. Graham, 301 S.C. 128, 390 S.E.2d 469 (Ct. App. 1990); 
  see also Roe v. Roe, 311 S.C. 471, 429 S.E.2d 830 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
  Moreover, a transfer of these funds from one party to the other as a part of 
  an equitable division should not result in a tax consequence.Â  Josey v. Josey, 
  291 S.C. 26, 351 S.E.2d 891 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  Here, the parties were awarded 
  their respective accounts.Â  Because we see no need for the accounts to be liquidated, 
  we hold the family court erred in valuing the partiesâ€™ retirement accounts at 
  48% of their face values.Â  In redetermining equitable distribution, the family 
  court shall consider the face values of the partiesâ€™ retirement accounts.

Id. at 289, 473 
  S.E.2d at 884-85.
After Ellerbe, 
  this Court, in Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 
  2002), examined tax effects as applied to the valuation and distribution of 
  the husbandâ€™s 401(k) account.Â  Bowers explicates:

We further find no error in the Family Courtâ€™s failure to 
  expressly consider tax consequences resulting from its award to Wife of one-half 
  the value of Husbandâ€™s 401(k) account.Â  Where an order of equitable apportionment 
  does not contemplate the liquidation or sale of an asset, it is an abuse of 
  discretion for the court to consider the tax consequences from a supposed sale 
  or liquidation.Â  Ellerbe v. Ellerbe, 323 S.C. 283, 473 S.E.2d 881 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  Here, the courtâ€™s order does not require or contemplate liquidation 
  of Husbandâ€™s 401(k) account and there is no evidence indicating either party 
  anticipated liquidation of the account.

Id. at 97-98, 561 
  S.E.2d at 617.
I reject the 
  contention by Husband that the apportionment of marital property in the case 
  sub judice contemplates the liquidation or sale of an asset.Â  
  The courtâ€™s order does not require or contemplate liquidation of Husbandâ€™s retirement 
  accounts or the sale of the house.Â  Husband asseverates that, in actuality, 
  he will be required to liquidate either the retirement accounts or to sell the 
  house or both in an attempt to comply financially with the courtâ€™s distribution.
In contrariety to Husbandâ€™s argument, there is no evidence indicating 
  he will be required to engage in a liquidation of the retirement accounts or 
  to sell the house, other than his self-serving assertions.Â  The Family Court 
  did not err in failing to expressly consider tax consequences resulting from 
  its award to Wife of the house.
IV.Â  Alimony
Husband contends the Family Courtâ€™s award to Wife of $4,300 per month in permanent 
  periodic alimony was excessive.Â  I agree.
The decision to grant or deny alimony rests within the discretion of the Family 
  Court judge.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 569 S.E.2d 367 (2002); 
  Clardy v. Clardy, 266 S.C. 270, 222 S.E.2d 771 (1976); Hatfield v. 
  Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 489 S.E.2d 212 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The judgeâ€™s discretion, 
  when exercised in light of the facts of each particular case, will not be disturbed 
  on appeal absent abuse thereof.Â  Dearybury, 351 S.C. at 282, 569 S.E.2d 
  at 369; Long v. Long, 247 S.C. 250, 146 S.E.2d 873 (1966).Â  An abuse 
  of discretion occurs when the judge is controlled by some error of law or where 
  the order, based upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary support.Â  Sharps 
  v. Sharps, 342 S.C. 71, 535 S.E.2d 913 (2000); Stewart v. Floyd, 
  274 S.C. 437, 265 S.E.2d 254 (1980).
Alimony is a substitute for the support which is normally incident to the marital 
  relationship.Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 384 S.E.2d 741 (1989); 
  Morris v. Morris, 335 S.C. 525, 517 S.E.2d 720 (Ct. App. 1999); Johnson 
  v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 372 S.E.2d 107 (Ct. App. 1988). Generally, alimony 
  should place the supported spouse, as nearly as is practical, in the same position 
  of support he or she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 
  S.C. 177, 554 S.E.2d 421 (Ct. App. 2001); McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 
  583, 506 S.E.2d 1 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  It is the duty of the Family Court to make 
  an alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just if the claim is well founded.Â  
  Hinson v. Hinson, 341 S.C. 574, 535 S.E.2d 143 (Ct. App. 2000); Woodward 
  v. Woodward, 294 S.C. 210, 363 S.E.2d 413 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Alimony should 
  not, however, serve as a disincentive for spouses to improve their employment 
  potential or to dissuade them from providing, to the extent possible, for their 
  own support.Â  Williamson v. Williamson, 311 S.C. 47, 426 S.E.2d 758 (1993); 
  McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 506 S.E.2d 1 (Ct. App. 1998); Brandi 
  v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 353, 396 S.E.2d 124 (Ct. App. 1990).
In making an award of alimony, the following factors must be considered and 
  weighed: (1) the duration of the marriage and ages of the parties at the time 
  of the marriage and at the time of the divorce; (2) the physical and emotional 
  condition of each spouse; (3) the educational background of each spouse, together 
  with the need of each spouse for additional training or education in order to 
  achieve that spouseâ€™s income potential; (4) the employment history and earning 
  potential of each spouse; (5) the standard of living established during the 
  marriage; (6) the current and reasonably anticipated earnings of both spouses; 
  (7) the current and reasonably anticipated expenses and needs of both spouses; 
  (8) the properties of the parties, including those apportioned to him or her 
  in the divorce or separate maintenance action; (9) custody of the children; 
  (10) marital misconduct or fault of either or both parties if the misconduct 
  has affected the economic circumstances of the parties, or contributed to the 
  breakup of the marriage; (11) tax consequences; (12) existence of any support 
  obligations from a prior marriage; and (13) such other factors the court considers 
  relevant.Â  Dearybury, 351 S.C. at 282-83, 569 S.E.2d at 369; Patel 
  v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 555 S.E.2d 386 (2001); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) 
  (Supp. 2002).Â  No one factor is dispositive.Â  Lide v. Lide, 277 S.C. 
  155, 283 S.E.2d 832 (1981); Allen, 347 S.C. at 184, 554 S.E.2d at 425.
I am compelled to agree with Husband that, in this case, 
  the Family Court arrived at an excessive amount in determining Wifeâ€™s award 
  of alimony.Â  At the time of trial, Husband was fifty-one years old and earned 
  about $217,000 annually.Â  Wife was fifty-two years old, employed as a Deputy 
  Coroner for Charleston County, and earned approximately $47,000 annually, or 
  $3,924 per month.Â  According to Wifeâ€™s financial declaration, her total monthly 
  expenses (including, inter alia, the mortgage on the marital home, 
  $250 for anticipated credit card payments, $300 for anticipated lien payments 
  on a new car, and a $789 entertainment expense) amount to about $5,730 per month.Â  
  Consequently, the Family Courtâ€™s award of $4,300 per month to the wife in alimony, 
  added to her net monthly income of $2,552, would afford her a monthly income 
  of $6,852, thereby exceeding her needs by approximately $1,122 per month.
Although Wife established 
  entitlement to alimony, the amount of the Family Courtâ€™s award is excessive 
  and amounts to an abuse of discretion.Â  Accordingly, I vote to reverse the amount 
  of alimony awarded and modify the Family Courtâ€™s order to reduce the award of 
  permanent periodic alimony to $3,000 per month.
V.Â  Attorneyâ€™s 
  Fees and Costs
Husband maintains the Family Court erred in ordering him to contribute $52,917.21 
  towards Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  I disagree.
Under South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(H) (Supp. 2002), 
  the judge may order one party to pay a reasonable amount to the other for attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs incurred in maintaining an action for divorce.Â  Smith v. Smith, 
  327 S.C. 448, 486 S.E.2d 516 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  An award of attorneyâ€™s fees will 
  not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 
  295 S.C. 412, 368 S.E.2d 901 (1988); Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 
  536 S.E.2d 427 (Ct. App. 2000); see also Woodall v. Woodall, 322 
  S.C. 7, 471 S.E.2d 154 (1996) (award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is within 
  sound discretion of Family Court judge).Â  Before awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, the 
  Family Court should consider (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own 
  fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective 
  financial conditions; and (4) the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s 
  standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992); 
  Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 543 S.E.2d 224 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In determining 
  the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to award, the court should consider: (1) the nature, 
  extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; (2) the time necessarily devoted 
  to the case; (3) counselâ€™s professional standing; (4) the contingency of compensation; 
  (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6) the customary legal fees for similar 
  services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991); 
  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002).
Here, Husband abandoned the marital home, began an adulterous affair, refused 
  to participate in marital counseling in any meaningful way, rejected Wifeâ€™s 
  attempts at reconciliation, and decided to commence marital litigation, thereby 
  putting Wife to the task of defending against the action.Â  In addition, the 
  issues of equitable apportionment and distribution were highly contested at 
  trial and, notwithstanding this Courtâ€™s modifications to the Family Courtâ€™s 
  order on appeal, Wifeâ€™s attorney obtained several beneficial results on her 
  behalf, including an award of divorce on the ground of adultery and an equal 
  division of the marital estate.
Having reviewed the award of attorneyâ€™s fees in light 
  of the applicable factors, I conclude the Family Court did not abuse its discretion.Â  
  There is sufficient evidentiary support in the record to uphold the judgeâ€™s 
  award of attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
I vote to reverse the Family Courtâ€™s order identifying $12,332 in credit card 
  charges as marital debt subject to equitable division, and in allocating the 
  debt to Husband.Â  Wife made no showing and the record did not reveal that the 
  credit card debts Wife incurred during the partiesâ€™ separation were incurred 
  for any purpose inuring to the benefit of Husband.Â  Moreover, these credit card 
  charges were incurred by Wife subsequent to the filing of marital litigation.Â  
  Thus, the debt should not have been allocated to Husband.
Although Wife established entitlement to alimony, the amount of the Family 
  Courtâ€™s award is excessive and amounts to an abuse of discretion.Â  Accordingly, 
  I vote to reverse the amount of alimony awarded and modify the Family Courtâ€™s 
  order to reduce the award of permanent periodic alimony from $4,300 to $3,000 
  per month.
The court did not err in awarding Wife the marital home in partial realization 
  of her share in the marital estate.Â  In addition, the Family Court properly 
  ordered Husband to contribute $52,917.21 towards Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and 
  costs.Â  I vote to affirm the judgeâ€™s rulings regarding the marital home and 
  the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.
For the foregoing reasons, I vote to affirm in part, reverse in part, 
  and modify in part.

 
   
    [1]  The marital estate consisted of the marital home valued at $675,000, 
    with equity of $539,349; Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts valued at $844,026; 
    Wifeâ€™s retirement account valued at $11,077; and, Husbandâ€™s interest in his 
    medical practice valued at $41,000.Â  

 
   [2] Â  We express no opinion as to whether or not the 
    family court could have required Husband to reimburse Wife for some or all 
    of these charges as an incident of support.

 
   [3] Â  Husband had already contributed $25,547.50 toward 
    Wifeâ€™s fees at the time of trial for a total award of $75,129.21.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Christopher Douglas Paris, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Union County
Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3611
Submitted January 10, 2003 - Filed March 
  17, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John Dennis Delgado, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles 
  H. Richardson; Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, of Columbia; 
  Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York; for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:  Christopher Douglas Paris appeals 
  his conviction for criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree.Â  
  The sole issue he raises on appeal is whether the trial court erred in refusing 
  his plea of nolo contendere. [1] Â  We find no abuse of discretion 
  and affirm. [2] 
After a jury was selected 
  but before it could be sworn, Paris entered a nolo contendere plea to the indictment 
  with a recommendation from the State that his sentence not exceed five years 
  of â€œactual prison timeâ€ with probation to follow.Â  The trial court determined 
  Paris was making the plea freely, voluntarily, and intelligently.Â  It found 
  the facts as presented by the State and reflected in Parisâ€™ prior statements 
  supported the plea.Â  
When questioned by the trial court regarding 
  whether he had anything to say to the court, Paris said he knew the crime had 
  not happened but was not going to contest the charge because he did not feel 
  like putting his child through a trial.Â  Upon hearing this, the trial court 
  altered course and told Paris it would not accept his plea after all.Â  Paris 
  again told the court he did not wish to contest the charge.Â  The trial court, 
  however, held to its position, notwithstanding Paris and his counsel urged the 
  court to accept his plea.Â  It refused to accept Parisâ€™ plea because Paris insisted 
  on his innocence.Â  The trial court told Paris it would not accept the plea unless 
  Paris admitted he committed the crime.Â  Paris would not do so, telling the trial 
  court, â€œI couldnâ€™t sit up here and tell you I did do it.â€Â  
Thereupon, the jury was sworn, a trial 
  was held, and Paris was convicted.Â  The trial court sentenced Paris to ten years 
  imprisonment but suspended the sentence upon service by Paris of five years 
  imprisonment and five years probation.Â  Paris appeals, claiming the trial court 
  abused its discretion when it refused to accept his nolo contendere plea solely 
  because he would not admit his guilt.Â  Paris also claims the trial court deprived 
  him of the benefit of his bargain with the State because he lost the â€œpossibilityâ€ 
  of receiving a lesser sentence.Â  
Paris relies upon North Carolina v. 
  Alford [3]  and United States v. Gaskins [4]  for the proposition that a trial court commits 
  an abuse of discretion when it refuses to accept a defendantâ€™s guilty plea solely 
  because the defendant will not admit the alleged facts of the crime.Â  
As to the Alford case, the Supreme Court 
  merely held the Constitution does not prohibit the acceptance of a guilty 
  plea despite protestations by the defendant of his or her innocence.Â  The case 
  has nothing whatever to do with the rejection of guilty pleas. 
  [5] Â  
As to the Gaskins case, other courts have 
  either rejected it outright or declined to follow it. 
  [6] Â  We likewise reject it and hold like a majority of the federal circuits 
  who have considered the question that a trial court â€œcan indeed reject a guilty 
  plea because the defendant protests innocence.â€ [7] Â  As the court pointed out in Bednarski, â€œa conviction 
  affects more than the court and the defendant; the public is involved . . . 
  . [T]he public might well not understand or accept the fact that a defendant 
  who denied his guilt was nonetheless placed in a position of pleading guilty 
  and going to jail . . . .â€ [8] 
Paris argues he â€œlost the bargain offered by the 
  State of the possibility of receiving a sentence [of] less than five yearsâ€ 
  when the trial court refused to accept his plea.Â  First, the trial court was 
  not required to accept the Stateâ€™s recommendation as to the sentence Paris should 
  receive. [9] Â  Second, he got 
  essentially the same sentence the State had agreed to recommend to the trial 
  court, i.e., five years of actual imprisonment followed by probation.
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â  
HEARN, C.J., and SHULER, JJ.
concur. 

 
   [1] Â  For all practical purposes, a plea of nolo contendere 
    is a plea of guilty in the particular case.Â  State v. Munsch, 287 S.C. 
    313, 338 S.E.2d 329 (1985); Kibler v. State, 267 S.C. 250, 227 S.E.2d 
    199 (1976); see 21 Am. Jur. 2d Criminal Law Â§ 728, at 703 (1998) 
    (stating that a plea of nolo contendere is the functional or substantive equivalent 
    of a guilty plea).

 
   [2] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [3] Â  400 U.S. 25 (1970).

 
   [4] Â  485 F.2d 1046 (D.C. Cir. 1973).

 
   [5] Â  400 U.S. at 38 n.11; United States v. Cox, 
    923 F.2d 519, 524-25 (7th Cir. 1991).

 
   [6] Â  Cox,Â  923 F.2d at 525 n.3; United States 
    v. Gomez-Gomez, 822 F.2d 1008, 1011 (11th Cir. 1987);Â  United States 
    v. Oâ€™Brien, 601 F.2d 1067, 1069-70 (9th Cir. 1979); United States v. 
    Biscoe, 518 F.2d 95, 96 (1st Cir. 1975); United States v. Bednarski, 
    445 F.2d 364, 366 (1st Cir. 1971).Â  

 
   [7] Â  Cox, 923 F.2d at 524.Â  

 
   [8] Â  Bednarski, 445 F.2d at 366.

 
   [9] Â  See State v. Riddle, 278 S.C. 148, 
    292 S.E.2d 795 (1982).

description: The issue on appeal is whether the trial judge erred in not recusing himself because he was the deputy solicitor both when the crimes were committed and when Jackson was arrested.  We find no error and affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Patrick Jackson, Appellant.
      
    
  

        
Appeal From Orangeburg County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3612
Heard January 16, 2003 - Filed March 
  17, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Daniel T. Stacey, of SC Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka; 
  Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, of Columbia; Solicitor Walter 
  M. Bailey, Jr., of Summerville; for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Patrick Jackson was convicted 
  of and received concurrent sentences for murder, kidnapping, armed robbery, 
  and carjacking. [1] Â  Jackson 
  appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Prior to the commencement 
  of trial, defense counsel put a motion for recusal on the record, having made 
  the original motion in the trial judgeâ€™s chambers.Â  The basis for the motion 
  was that the trial judge was the deputy solicitor in Orangeburg County both 
  when the crimes were committed and when Jackson was arrested.Â  The judge was 
  sworn in two days after Jacksonâ€™s arrest.Â  Defense counsel argued that the judge 
  should recuse himself because he had been the â€œchief law enforcement officerâ€ 
  for the county during crucial points in the history of the case.Â  The judge 
  denied the motion, stating he had no knowledge of the case and had never discussed 
  it with anyone from the solicitorâ€™s office or â€œany law enforcement agency.â€
LAW/ANALYSIS
Jackson contends the trial judge erred in denying the motion to 
  recuse.Â  We find this contention is without merit.
Pursuant to Canon 3(E)(1)(a) of 
  Rule 501, SCACR, a judge should disqualify himself or herself in a proceeding 
  in which the judgeâ€™s impartiality might reasonably be questioned. 
  [2] Â  It is not enough for a party seeking disqualification to simply allege 
  bias or prejudice.Â  The party must show some evidence of that bias or prejudice. 
  [3] Â  The alleged bias or prejudice must stem from an extra-judicial source 
  and result in a decision based on information other than what the judge learned 
  from his or her participation in the case as a judge. 
  [4] Â  If there is no evidence of judicial bias or prejudice, a judgeâ€™s failure 
  to disqualify himself will not be reversed on appeal. 
  [5] 
The fact that the trial judge in this 
  case was a deputy solicitor at the time Jackson allegedly committed the crime 
  did not automatically warrant his recusal from the case without more. [6] Â  The trial judge was unfamiliar with the case 
  and had not discussed it, either with employees of the solicitorâ€™s office or 
  with any law enforcement agency.Â  Indeed, Jackson offered no proof to the contrary. 
  [7] 
We further note the ultimate outcome of the case, 
  Jacksonâ€™s conviction, is fully supported by the record. 
  [8] Â  Jackson signed a statement in which he admitted:Â  he was present at 
  the commission of the crimes, he drove the carjacked vehicle, and he owned a 
  green Honda Accord.Â  Jackson also identified one of his co-conspirators in a 
  photo lineup.Â  Eyewitness testimony placed Jackson and at least one of his co-conspirators 
  in a green Accord.Â  A green Accord was seen trailing the carjacked vehicle.Â  
  Jacksonâ€™s sister also testified that, on the day of the carjacking, she witnessed 
  Jackson and one of his co-conspirators walking down the dirt road where the 
  carjacked vehicle and the victimâ€™s body were eventually found.Â  Given the strength 
  of the evidence offered against Jackson at trial, there is no reason to question 
  the trial judgeâ€™s impartiality. [9] 
CONCLUSION
We find there was no error in the trial 
  judgeâ€™s denial of Jacksonâ€™s motion for recusal. [10] Â  There is no reason to challenge the trial 
  judgeâ€™s impartiality in this matter because the outcome of the case is supported 
  by the record. [11] Â  Accordingly, Jacksonâ€™s convictions and sentences 
  are
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF and SHULER,
JJ., concur.

 
    [1] Â  Jackson also received a consecutive sentence 
    for contempt of court.

 
    [2] Â  See also Murphy v. Murphy, 
    319 S.C. 324, 461 S.E.2d 39 (1995).

 
    [3] Â  Roche v. Young Bros., Inc., of Florence, 
    332 S.C. 75, 504 S.E.2d 311 (1998).

 
    [4] Â  Payne v. Holiday Towers, Inc., 283 S.C. 
    210, 321 S.E.2d 179 (Ct. App. 1984).

 
    [5] Â  Ellis v. Procter & Gamble Distrib. Co., 
    315 S.C. 283, 433 S.E.2d 856 (1993).

 
    [6] Â  See Commw. v. Darush, 501 Pa. 15, 
    459 A.2d 727 (Pa. 1983) (holding that the trial court judge did not abuse 
    his discretion in refusing to recuse himself on the basis that the offenses 
    for which the defendant was convicted occurred when the trial judge was serving 
    as district attorney, where he had taken a statement from a primary witness 
    in the instant case and had prosecuted the defendant on unrelated charges); 
    see also Laird v. Tatum, 409 U.S. 824 (1972) (where then-Justice 
    Rehnquist held that his recusal was not warranted merely because he was an 
    Assistant Attorney General while Laird was being investigated and prosecuted 
    because Rehnquist did not have any advisory role in any matters involving 
    Laird, had never signed a pleading or brief regarding the case, and had never 
    personally participated in the trial or appeal); Donald v. Jones, 445 
    F.2d 601 (5th Cir. 1971) (holding that the defendant was not deprived of a 
    fair and impartial trial because the judge who presided at his pretrial hearing 
    was first assistant district attorney at the time of the commission of the 
    offense because the judge had never heard of the defendant prior to assuming 
    the bench, had not participated in the investigation of the case, and did 
    not sit at the actual trial); Commw. v. Jones, 541 Pa. 351, 663 A.2d 
    142 (Pa. 1995) (holding that although the judgeâ€™s name had appeared on papers 
    in connection with the defendantâ€™s conviction, which had occurred while the 
    judge was a district attorney, this did not warrant recusal absent a showing 
    that the judge had any direct personal contact with defendantâ€™s case during 
    his prosecution and conviction); Rule 501, SCACR, Code of Jud. Conduct Cannon 
    3(E)(1)(a) (Commentary).

 
    [7] Â  See Roche, 332 S.C. at 85, 504 
    S.E.2d at 316 (â€œIf there is no evidence of judicial prejudice, a judgeâ€™s failure 
    to disqualify himself will not be reversed on appeal.â€).

 
    [8] Â  A judge is not required to recuse himself when 
    no evidence is presented other than claimed adverse rulings by the judge.Â  
    Payne, 283 S.C. at 217, 321 S.E.2d at 183.

 
    [9] Â  See Ellis, 315 S.C. at 285, 433 
    S.E.2d at 857.

 
    [10] Â  For a general discussion of this particular 
    issue, see Jay M. Zitter, Prior Representation or Activity as Prosecuting 
    Attorney As Disqualifying Judge from Sitting or Acting in Criminal Case, 
    85 A.L.R. 5th 471 Â§ 3 (2001).

 
    [11] Â 
  See Roche at 85, 504 S.E.2d at 
    316.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
R.C. McEntire, Jr., and Pamela T.
McEntire, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Mooregard Exterminating Services, Inc.,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3613
Submitted January 10, 2003 - Filed March 
  17, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas Bailey Smith, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
William S. Duncan, of Georgetown, for Respondents.
      
    
  

 GOOLSBY, J.:Â 
R.C. McEntire, Jr. 
  and Pamela T. McEntire brought this action against Mooregard Exterminating Services, 
  Inc., alleging, among other things, the breach of a termite contact.Â  The jury 
  found for Mooregard Exterminating.Â  The McEntires filed a post-trial motion, 
  seeking a new trial pursuant to the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  They also sought 
  a judgment notwithstanding the verdict and, alternatively, a new trial.Â  At 
  no time during the trial itself did the McEntires move for a directed verdict.Â  
  The trial court granted the McEntires â€œa new trial upon the facts,â€ as a ruling 
  pursuant to the thirteenth juror doctrine is also called.1Â  
  Mooregard Exterminating appeals, contending a party must make a directed verdict 
  or similar motion before a trial court can grant a new trial based on the facts.Â  
  We disagree and therefore affirm.2
In Folkens, the supreme court held 
  a trial judgeâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial based on the thirteenth 
  juror doctrine will not be disturbed unless the trial judgeâ€™s â€œdecision is wholly 
  unsupported by the evidence or the conclusion reached was controlled by an error 
  of law.â€3Â  Here, the 
  issue raised by Mooregard Exterminating does not question the sufficiency of 
  the evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s ruling; rather, it argues his decision 
  was controlled by an error of law.
Although, as Mooregard Exterminating contends, 
  a directed verdict motion is a prerequisite to a motion for judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict4 or for 
  a motion for a new trial on the ground that the evidence does not support the 
  verdict,5 we know of 
  no caseâ€”and Mooregard Exterminating cites none to usâ€”in which either the supreme 
  court or the court of appeals, at least since the adoption of the South Carolina 
  Rules of Civil Procedure, has held a trial judge lacks the power to grant a 
  new trial upon the facts if the moving party earlier failed to make a directed 
  verdict or an equivalent motion.6
The granting of a new trial upon the facts 
  is not the equivalent of granting a directed verdict.7Â  A directed verdict is warranted when 
  â€œthe case presents only questions of lawâ€8 
  and â€œshould be allowed only if the evidence would not be legally sufficient 
  to sustain a verdict for the opposite party.â€9Â  The question of whether 
  the evidence adduced by a party can support a verdict in the partyâ€™s favor is 
  a question of law.10Â Â  
On the other hand, a trial judge may grant 
  a new trial upon the facts if the judge determines the verdict â€œis contrary 
  to the fair preponderance of the evidence.â€11Â  
  Unlike a motion for directed verdict, the trial judge weighs the evidence under 
  the thirteenth juror doctrine12 
  and need not view it in the light most favorable to the opposing party.13Â  
  Moreover, the question of whether to grant a new trial upon the facts is one 
  addressed to the discretion of the trial judge.14 
 

Because the question of whether the evidence 
  is legally sufficient to support a verdictâ€”a question of lawâ€”is totally different 
  from the question of whether the fair preponderance of the evidence supports 
  a verdictâ€”a question involving the exercise of discretionâ€”there is no inconsistency 
  in a partyâ€™s failure to move for a directed verdict and a partyâ€™s moving to 
  have the verdict set aside as being against the fair preponderance of the evidence.15Â  
  Stated differently, â€œ[i]t may well be that a partyâ€™s evidence makes a case for 
  the jury while it is so outweighed by the countervailing evidence that, in the 
  exercise of its discretion, the trial court should not hesitate to set aside 
  the verdict in his favor.â€16 
 

A motion for a directed verdict or similar motion, 
  therefore, was not a prerequisite to a motion to set aside the verdict on the 
  ground the verdict was contrary to the fair preponderance of the evidence.
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and SHULER, J., concur.

 
  1Â 
  Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 
    254, 387 S.E.2d 265, 267 (1990).

 
  2Â  Because oral argument would not aid the 
    court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral 
    argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
  3Â  300 S.C. at 254-55, 387 S.E.2d at 267.

 
  4Â 
  Johnson v. Hoechst Celanese Corp., 
    317 S.C. 415, 420, 453 S.E.2d 908, 911 (Ct. App. 1995).

 
  5Â 
  Peay v. Ross, 292 S.C. 535, 537, 
    357 S.E.2d 482, 483 (Ct. App. 1987).

 
  6Â  We are aware of Scott v. Seymour, 
    105 S.C. 42, 89 S.E. 398 (1916), a South Carolina case which can be read as 
    holding that a motion for a new trial on the ground the verdict was contrary 
    to the evidence could not be sustained because the appellant failed to make 
    a motion for a nonsuit or for a directed verdict as required by what was then 
    Rule 77 of the Circuit Court Rules.Â  See 66 C.J.S. New Trial 
    Â§ 69c, at 205 (1950) (citing Scott and stating:Â  â€œGenerally a new trial 
    on the ground that a verdict is against the evidence . . . will not be refused 
    because the movant failed to ask that the case be taken from the jury, but 
    some decisions apparently follow a contrary rule . . . .â€) (footnotes omitted).Â  
    Rule 77 (which later became Rule 76), however, no longer exists.Â  See 
    Rule 86, SCRCP (making July 1, 1985, the effective date of the South Carolina 
    Rules of Civil Procedure).

 
  7Â 
  See 58 Am. Jur. 2d New Trial 
    Â§ 3, at 86-87 (2002) (â€œA motion for a new trial is governed by a different 
    standard than a motion for a directed verdict.â€).

 
  8Â  Rule 50(a),
  SCRCP.

 
  9Â  58 Am. Jur. 2d New Trial Â§ 3, at 
    87.

 
  10  Id. Â§ 4, at 87.

 
  11  Dent v. Redd, 270 S.C. 585, 586, 
    243 S.E.2d 460, 460 (1978).

 
  12  Ridings v. Norfolk S. Ry. Co., 
    894 S.W.2d 281, 288 (Tenn. Ct. App. 1994).

 
  13  See Parker v. Evening Post 
    Publâ€™g Co., 317 S.C. 236, 247, 452 S.E.2d 640, 646 (Ct. App. 1994) (stating 
    the trial court may take its own view of the evidence).

 
  14  South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t 
    v. Clarkson, 267 S.C. 121, 126, 226 S.E.2d 696, 697 (1976).

 
  15  Russell v. Pilger, 37 A.2d 403, 
    414 (Vt. 1944).

 
  16  Id.

title: Hurd v. Williamsburg
description: Jack Hurd initiated this action under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act against Williamsburg County and Williamsburg County Transit Authority.  In a jury trial, Hurd was awarded $675,000 in damages.  The verdict was reduced under the mandatory cap to $250,000.  The court found the governmental entities breached a duty of safety they owed to Hurd.  Additionally, the court ruled Hurd presented evidence to support a holding of proximate cause.  Finally, the issue of comparative neglience is discussed with specificity.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jack Hurd, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Williamsburg County and 
Williamsburg County Transit 
Authority, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3614
Heard January 15, 2003 - Filed March 
  17, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles E. Carpenter, Jr. and S. Elizabeth Brosnan, of 
  Columbia; Robin B. Lilley and Stephen Paul Bucher, of Charleston; for Appellants.
Ladson Fishburne Howell, Jr., 
  and Richard G. Wern, of N. Charleston; Ronnie Alan Sabb, of Kingstree; for Respondent.
      
    
  

 ANDERSON, J.:Â  Jack Hurd 
  brought this tort action against Williamsburg County and Williamsburg County 
  Transit Authority (collectively referred to as the â€œCountyâ€), alleging damages 
  resulting from an automobile-pedestrian collision that occurred when he was 
  struck by an automobile after exiting a bus.Â  A jury trial was held and Hurd 
  was awarded $675,000 in damages.Â  The verdict was reduced under the mandate 
  of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  The County appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Hurd boarded the Countyâ€™s bus around 6 
  a.m. on February 1, 1996 to go to work in Myrtle Beach.Â  The bus driver usually 
  drove another route, but was substituting for the regular driver that day.Â  
  The bus route starts in the Sand Ridge Community, travels through Highway 261 
  to Highway 24, comes down to Highway 41/51 at Mingoâ€™s crossing, then goes through 
  Georgetown and Highway 17 to Myrtle Beach.
On the morning of the accident, the bus 
  driver pulled off onto the shoulder of Highway 41, a two-lane road, after several 
  passengers requested he stop there so that they could get breakfast across the 
  road at Mingoâ€™s Store.Â  The normal procedure was for the bus driver to stop 
  further down at the â€œPark and Ride,â€ which is located on the same side of the 
  road as Mingoâ€™s Store.Â  The â€œPark and Rideâ€ was erected by the County to serve 
  as a transfer station for riders because of the congestion in the Highway 41 
  area.
After several passengers alighted onto 
  the shoulder, Hurd, who had been sleeping, awoke and asked the bus driver to 
  let him off so that he could also go to Mingoâ€™s store.Â  According to the bus 
  driver, he informed Hurd he was going to the â€œPark and Rideâ€ and that Hurd could 
  disembark there and go to Mingoâ€™s.Â  Hurd, however, requested to go with the 
  other passengers.
Hurd exited and walked to the rear of 
  the bus.Â  At trial, he claimed he looked to the left and right and did not see 
  any vehicles on the highway.Â  He stated he began to cross the highway when the 
  bus started to pull away and was at an angle so he could not see to his right.Â  
  Hurd continued across the highway and was struck by a car coming from the opposite 
  direction.Â  Hurd asserted:Â  â€œI tried to look around the day that I got hit and 
  my view was blocked, thatâ€™s why I go [sic] hit.â€Â  Hurd sustained substantial 
  injuries as a result of being hit.
Booker Pressley, a former director of 
  the Countyâ€™s transit authority, testified that the â€œPark and Rideâ€ on Highway 
  41 was built because of the traffic congestion in the area and concern about 
  rider safety.Â  Pressley contended that the transit authority had a policy that 
  the drivers were to let the passengers off at the â€œPark and Ride.â€Â  Pressley 
  maintained he issued a written warning to the bus driver following the accident 
  for failing to discharge the passengers at the â€œPark and Ride.â€Â  At his deposition, 
  published to the jury, he declared:

  
    
       Q.
       
  After the establishment of the Park & Ride were the drivers advised that 
  they werenâ€™t to use the shoulder of the road to discharge passengers anymore, 
  that they were to use the Park & Ride?
    
    
      A.
       We had meetings and the 
  meetings were that every driver would meet down at Mingoâ€™s and get down there 
  between the time of a quarter to seven and twenty minutes to seven so they could 
  make their change of the bus.Â  We also talked about you know, it was [sic] thing 
  where we talk about everybody pulling up over there.Â  When we went in there 
  that was a woods area.Â  We were able to get a whole side cleaned up to the store 
  so the passengers wouldnâ€™t have to cross the road.
    
    
      Q. 
       Were the drivers told 
  not to discharge the passengers on the side of the road after the Park & 
  Ride was created?
    
    
      A.
       I think every driver 
  was told, and somehow I think theyâ€”now, if they was [sic] doing it I didnâ€™t 
  know anything about it.Â  Because I used to go down there quite a few times and 
  monitor that because we have some sites in Williamsburg County thatâ€™s creeping 
  fast.Â  What I mean is thereâ€™s a lot of traffic and it comes in until you kind 
  of, you know it shoots right up on you.
    
    
      Q.
       You were monitoring this 
  area to make sure the drivers werenâ€™t discharging passengers on the side of 
  41?
    
    
      A.
       I monitored all areas, 
  Myrtle Beach and all the areas.
    
    
      
       . . . .
    
    
      Q.
       Is safety a consideration 
  when letting a passenger off the bus?
    
    
      A.
       Yes.
    
    
      Q.
       In what way?
    
    
      A.
       Well, again, just like 
  I said Mingoâ€™s is one of those little areas that was congested and thatâ€™s why 
  we started.Â  What we did was we started a Park & Ride site in the congested 
  area first.
    
    
      Q.
       Do you agree that the 
  different discharge areas involve different risks?
    
    
      A.
       Yes.
    
    
      Q.
       And would you agree that 
  some areas are safer than others?
    
    
      A.
       Yes.
    
    
      Q.
       Would you agree that 
  the Park & Ride area established behind Mingoâ€™s store is a safer area to 
  discharge passengers than on the side of the highway?
    
    
      A.
       Yes.
    
    
      
       . . . .
    
    
      Q.
       Do you have any knowledge 
  about accident or fatalities occurring at that intersection?
    
    
      A.
       Well, Mingoâ€™s when I

  passenger safety, the driver decided to violate the Countyâ€™s policies and debus 
  the passengers on the shoulder of the road.Â Â  In addition, Roberts concluded 
  that it was unreasonable and did â€œnot make any sense whatsoeverâ€ to discharge 
  passengers on the roadside rather than at the â€œPark and Ride.â€Â  Under the facts 
  of this case, we find Hurd presented evidence that allows a jury to draw a reasonable 
  inference that the Countyâ€™s negligence was greater than Hurdâ€™s negligence.
 AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
HEARN, C.J., concurs.
CURETON, J., dissents 
  in a separate opinion.
CURETON, J., dissenting:Â  I respectfully 
  dissent.Â  
I.
The majority contends that Hurd produced 
  sufficient evidence to establish that he was let off the bus in an unreasonably 
  dangerous location.Â  I disagree.
At trial, Hurd offered the deposition of Booker 
  Pressley, the former director of Williamsburg Countyâ€™s transit authority.Â  Pressley 
  stated that the area in which the â€œPark and Rideâ€ was created was congested.Â  
  Pressley attested that the â€œPark and Rideâ€ was created so that the passengers 
  would not have to cross the road to go to Mingoâ€™s store, and it was also established 
  to provide the County with a safer place to discharge its passengers than on 
  the side of the highway.Â Â  
 Hurd also presented testimony from Dr. Roberts, 
  an expert in the field of traffic and pedestrian safety design, that it was 
  unwise for the bus driver to have allowed passengers to disembark from the bus 
  on the shoulder of the highway when there was a â€œPark and Rideâ€ available.Â  
  However, Roberts further opined that it would be reasonable to drop passengers 
  off on the side of the road under the following circumstances:

[K]eep in mind that this is a rural area where 
  your passengers are going to be getting on and off in rural circumstances.Â  
  So â€¦ what you want is a location where you can let the passengers off where 
  hopefully you can get the bus completely off the traveled way and still have 
  room for the passengers to get off without ending up in the ditch or something 
  of this type.Â  Then the bus can move off, allow the passengers, if they need 
  to cross the roadway, a clear unobstructed view in either direction so they 
  can cross the road in a location which is reasonably convenient for the passengers.Â  


At trial Appellant presented evidence which clearly 
  showed that the shoulder of the road was adequate in size to allow the bus space 
  to pull completely off the roadway while still having adequate room for passengers 
  to disembark without stepping into a ditch, etc.Â  The shoulder was also sufficient 
  to enable the bus to reenter the roadway, while at the same time allowing the 
  passenger to safely stand in the shoulder and view both lanes of traffic so 
  that the passenger could then cross the roadway in a reasonably convenient location.Â  
  The majority points to the fact that when the bus moved to reenter the highway, 
  the bus was at an angle and Hurd testified he was unable to see to his right.Â  
  However, there is no evidence to show that the bus pulled onto the highway into 
  the oncoming lane of traffic traveling from the right and blocked Hurdâ€™s view 
  in that manner.Â  
A common carrier has a duty to exercise the highest 
  degree of care towards its passengers.Â  Singletary v. Atl. Coast Line R.R. 
  Co., 217 S.C. 212, 218, 60 S.E.2d 305, 307 (1950).Â  However, â€œthe relation 
  of passenger and carrier ordinarily ends when the passenger steps from a bus 
  into a reasonable safe place on a public highway.â€Â  Flynn v. Carolina Scenic 
  Stages, 237 S.C. 340, 345, 117 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1960).Â  Accord Harris 
  v. Atl. Greyhound Corp., 90 S.E.2d 710, 713 (N.C. 1956) (finding bus company 
  owes a passenger duty to provide a safe landing, but once passenger has alighted 
  safely to a place of safety, relationship of carrier and passenger ends).
The extent of Pressley and 
  Robertsâ€™s testimony was not that this particular shoulder was unsafe in and 
  of itself, but that this shoulder was unreasonably dangerous in light of the 
  fact that there was a safer location, a â€œPark and Ride,â€ a few hundred feet 
  away.Â  However, the threshold that must be met was that the carrier breached 
  a duty to Hurd because the carrier let him off the bus in an unreasonably dangerous 
  location. The evidence presented by Hurd does not meet this standard.Â Â  
II.
The majority found that 
  Hurd presented evidence that allowed an inference that the Countyâ€™s actions 
  were the proximate cause of the accident and that the countyâ€™s negligence was 
  greater than Hurdâ€™s negligence.Â  I disagree.Â Â  
Although comparison 
  of a plaintiffâ€™s negligence with that of a defendant is ordinarily a question 
  for the jury, the trial court should determine this question as a matter of 
  law if the â€œsole reasonable inference which may be drawn from the evidence is 
  that the plaintiffâ€™s negligence exceeded fifty percent.â€Â  Bloom v. Ravoira, 
  339 S.C. 417, 422, 529 S.E.2d 710, 713 (2000).Â  â€œWhere evidence of the plaintiffâ€™s 
  greater negligence is overwhelming, evidence of slight negligence on 
  the part of the defendant is simply not enough for a case to go to the jury.â€Â  
  Id. at 424, 529 S.E.2d at 714.
Hurd testified that he did 
  not have a clear view of the highway when he began to cross the street to reach 
  Mingoâ€™s store. He stated that he continued to cross the highway even though 
  the bus was blocking his ability to see oncoming traffic. Â Rather than 
  wait a brief moment on the shoulder for the bus to pull away, Hurd chose to 
  cross the highway despite his obstructed view.Â  Furthermore, Hurd requested 
  to be let out on the shoulder even though the driver informed him that he was 
  driving to the â€œPark and Rideâ€ where Hurd could have safely exited the bus and 
  walked to Mingoâ€™s store.Â  Hurdâ€™s own testimony established that he attempted 
  to cross the highway in an unreasonable and unsafe manner.Â Â  

A common carrier of passengers is due such passengers the 
  highest degree of care, but is not an insurer of the safety of passengers under 
  all circumstances. â€¦ In an action in tort based on negligence, the negligence 
  of the defendant must be the proximate cause of the injury to the plaintiff.Â  
  Even though there may be some testimony from which it could be inferred that 
  a defendant was negligent, a plaintiff cannot unnecessarily and consciously 
  take a risk which may or may not result in injury, and when it does result in 
  injury, then recover damages therefor against a defendant.Â  In other words, 
  the law requires that a passenger . . . should use every reasonable care to 
  avoid injury to himself, and if he fails to use such care as a man of ordinary 
  prudence and caution would have used under the surrounding circumstances, and 
  is injured as a result thereof, he cannot recover.Â  

Singletary,Â  217 S.C. atÂ  218-19, 60 S.E.2d at 307-308 
  (1950).Â  Under the facts of this case, I find that Hurd failed to present evidence 
  that the carrierâ€™s negligence was the proximate cause of his injuries or that 
  the Countyâ€™s negligence was greater than his own.Â  Accordingly, the trial court 
  erred in failing to direct a verdict in favor of the County.Â  
I would REVERSE and enter 
  judgment for Appellant.Â  
    Â
