THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Darnell Hudson East, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3615
Submitted January 10, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  17, 2003Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Haile, of Columbia; 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  allÂ  of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Darnell East was indicted for armed robbery 
  and seven counts of kidnapping.Â  The trial judge denied his motions for a directed 
  verdict on the charges of kidnapping. East was convicted on all counts and sentenced 
  to life without parole.Â Â  East appeals, asserting the trial judge erred in denying 
  his motion for a directed verdict on the kidnapping charges because the alleged 
  kidnapping was not a separate and distinct offense from the armed robbery.Â  
  He also contends the trial judge erred in denying his motion for a directed 
  verdict on the kidnapping charge as to Richard Ausburn because Ausburn did not 
  testify at trial.Â  We affirm. [1] 
I. FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Two men entered a fast-food restaurant in Powdersville 
  shortly before it opened on a Sunday morning.Â  One of the men had a knife and 
  said:Â  â€œThis is a robbery.â€Â  When the employee advised him that he did not have 
  the key to open the cash drawer, the robber with the knife and the employee 
  walked to the managerâ€™s office. The manager came to the door of the office, 
  and the robber grabbed the phone from the manager and cut the cord with the 
  knife.Â  Shortly thereafter, the other robber, East, came back to the managerâ€™s 
  office carrying a gun.Â  East grabbed the manager and took him into the office.Â  
  When East came out of the office with the manager, the two robbers told seven 
  of the employees to â€œlay (sic) on the ground.â€Â  The employees lay there for 
  several minutes until the robbers left the store.Â  Approximately twenty-three 
  hundred dollars was stolen from the store.Â  
At trial, the defense moved for a directed verdict 
  on the ground that the brief confinement of the victims during the course of 
  the armed robbery was not a separate and distinct offense.Â  A directed verdict 
  was also sought on the kidnapping charge as to one of the employees, Richard 
  Ausburn, because Ausburn â€œdid not appear and has not testified.â€ Relying primarily 
  on the case of State v. Hall, 280 S.C. 74, 310 S.E.2d 429 (1983), the 
  trial judge denied the motion for a directed verdict.Â  He also found the testimony 
  of other employees concerning Ausburnâ€™s presence during the robbery to be sufficient 
  to warrant a denial of the motion for a directed verdict as to that count of 
  kidnapping.Â  The jury convicted East of all charges.
II. ISSUE
East argues he was entitled to a directed verdict on the kidnapping charges 
  because the brief confinement of the employees during the course of the armed 
  robbery was not sufficient to constitute the separate crime of kidnapping.Â  
  East also argues he was entitled to a directed verdict on the kidnapping count 
  with respect to Richard Ausburn because Ausburn did not appear at trial and 
  did not testify.
III. DISCUSSION
S.C. Code Â§16-3-910 (Supp. 2001) defines the offense 
  of kidnapping as follows:Â  â€œWhoever shall unlawfully seize, confine, inveigle, 
  decoy, kidnap, abduct or carry away any other person by any means whatsoever 
  without authority of law, except when a minor is seized or taken by his parent, 
  is guilty of a felony . . . .â€Â  Kidnapping is a continuous offense which â€œcommences 
  when one is wrongfully deprived of freedom and continues until freedom is restored.â€Â  
  State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 13, 512 S.E.2d 99, 105 (1999).Â  South Carolinaâ€™s 
  kidnapping statute requires proof of an unlawful act taking one of several alternative 
  forms, including seizure, confinement, inveiglement, decoy, kidnapping, 
  [2]  abduction, or carrying away. See State v. Owens, 291 
  S.C. 116, 352 S.E.2d 474 (1987).Â  
The issue of whether the act of confinement can 
  constitute the separate offense of kidnapping when it is incidental to the commission 
  of another crime was raised in State v. Hall, 280 S.C. 74, 310 S.E.2d 
  429 (1983).Â  In Hall, the victim was abducted by knifepoint as she placed 
  a call from a phone booth near a clubhouse of an apartment complex.Â  The perpetrator 
  forced the victim to walk to an adjacent pool area where he sexually assaulted 
  her and forced her to walk to different locations around the pool.Â  At each 
  location, the victim was assaulted.Â  On appeal from his convictions for assault 
  and battery of a high and aggravated nature, first degree criminal sexual conduct, 
  and kidnapping, Hall argued the trial judge erred in failing to charge the jury 
  that in order to establish kidnapping, the State must prove the confining and 
  carrying away of the victim was more than incident to the commission of another 
  crime.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court disagreed, holding that Hallâ€™s restraint 
  of the victim constituted kidnapping within the meaning of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  16-3-910 (1976) â€œregardless of the fact that the purpose of this seizure was 
  to facilitate the commission of a sexual battery.â€Â  280 S.C. at 78, 310 S.E.2d 
  at 431.Â  
It appears that South Carolina may be in the minority 
  of jurisdictions which have considered this issue.Â  See State v. Anthony, 
  817 S.W.2d 299, 305 (Tenn. 1991) (citing to at least fifteen statesâ€™ appellate 
  court decisions on this issue and stating that â€œ[b]y an overwhelming margin, 
  the majority view in other jurisdictions is that kidnapping statutes do not 
  apply to unlawful confinements or movements incidental to the commission of 
  other crimes.â€); see also Model Penal Code Â§ 212.1 (2001) (requiring 
  movement over a substantial distance or confinement for a substantial period 
  of time).Â  Nevertheless, we agree with the trial judge here that the decision 
  of our supreme court in State v. Hall controls.
Moreover, we note that the trial judge charged 
  the jury that in order for it to convict East of both offenses, it must find 
  that he had the requisite intent to commit two separate offenses.Â  Although 
  the jury charge is not part of the record on appeal, the trial judge advised 
  counsel when he placed the results of the charge conference on the record and 
  stated:Â  

I am going to follow the lead of [defense counsel] in her 
  request from that Hall case that cites with approval the North Carolina 
  decision that in order to convict on the second series of offenses, the alleged 
  kidnappings, Iâ€™m going to quote from that case and make that charge.Â  And for 
  the record, it will be as follows:Â  â€œUnder the law, two or more criminal offenses 
  may grow out of the same course of action as where one offense is committed 
  with the intent thereafter to commit the other and is actually followed by the 
  commission of the other.â€

Thus, the jury was clearly instructed that in order 
  to convict East of both armed robbery and kidnapping, it would have to find 
  that he possessed the requisite intent to commit the second offense, in this 
  case, the kidnapping.
Regarding Eastâ€™s argument concerning the failure 
  of the State to call one of the victims as a witness, there was testimony in 
  the record from the other KFC employees that Ausburn was present when they were 
  confined in the hallway.Â  Accordingly, the trial judge properly denied the motion 
  for a directed verdict on this ground.Â  See State v. Charping, 
  333 S.C. 124, 129, 508 s.E.2d 851, 854 (1998) (â€œ[A]n adverse inference from 
  the unexplained failure of a party to call an available witness is generally 
  held not warranted when the material facts assumed to be within the knowledge 
  of the absent witness have been testified to by other qualified witnesses.â€);Â  
  State v. Creech, 314 S.C. 76, 82-83, 441 S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. App. 1994) 
  (â€œIn reviewing the refusal to grant a directed verdict, the evidence is viewed 
  in the light most favorable to the State to determine whether there is any evidence, 
  either direct or circumstantial, which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of 
  the accused, or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.â€)
Accordingly, Eastâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and SHULER, JJ. concur.    

 
   
     
    [1]    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215,
  SCACR.

 
    [2]    â€œAs used in Â§ 16-3-910, the term â€˜kidnapâ€™ apparently refers 
    to the common law crime of kidnapping.â€Â  State v. Berntsen, 295 S.C. 
    52, 54 n.1, 367 S.E.2d 152, 153 n.1 (1988).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Edgar Scott, as Parent and Natural Guardian of Zacharias Scott, a 
        Minor Under the Age of Fourteen Years, Appellant,
v.
Edgar Scott, as Parent and Natural Guardian of Zacharias Scott, a 
        Minor Under the Age of Fourteen Years, Appellant,
Greenville Housing Authority, as Owner and Operator of Pierce Homes,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3616
Heard February 11, 2003 â€“ Filed March 17, 2003

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
John Robert Peace, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Merl F. Code and E. Delane Rosemond, of Greenville, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Edgar Scott (Scott), a parent of a three-year-old boy 
  who was severely burned by a hot water heater at a Greenville Housing Authority 
  (GHA) property, appeals the jury verdict in GHAâ€™s favor.Â  Scott argues the trial 
  judge erred by refusing to hold GHA admitted liability pursuant to Rule 36, 
  SCRCP.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On February 7, 1998, Scott left his son, three-year-old Zacharias 
  Scott, with a babysitter in unit 62-A of Pierce Homes.Â  Pierce Homes is a property 
  owned and operated by GHA.Â  After going to the bathroom, Zacharias attempted 
  to wash his hands.Â  The water was so hot that it caused severe burns to his 
  hands.Â  Zacharias spent ten days in the hospital for his painful burns, which 
  required him to be placed under anesthesia prior to changing his bandages.Â  
  Over the next two years, Zacharias underwent several surgeries to improve the 
  appearance and range of motion in his hands.Â  Despite the surgeries, Zachariasâ€™ 
  hands were severely scarred and he incurred more than $23,000 in medical bills.
On January 4, 2000, Scott, on behalf of Zacharias, sued GHA, alleging 
  GHA was aware the hot water heater was improperly set and that GHAâ€™s grossly 
  negligent and reckless acts proximately caused Zachariasâ€™ injuries.Â  Scott sought 
  actual and punitive damages.Â  GHA denied liability and asserted that Scott was 
  responsible for the injuries for failing to properly supervise Zacharias and 
  Zacharias assumed the risk of burns by using only hot water to wash his hands.
The parties proceeded with discovery.Â  On November 15, 2000, Scott 
  served GHA with Supplemental Interrogatories and Requests for Production, requesting, 
  among other things, inspection records for the hot water heaters.Â  Thereafter, 
  on November 21, 2000, Scott served GHA with a First Set of Requests for Admission 
  and Supplemental Interrogatories.Â  Request to Admit numbers 3 and 4 asked GHA 
  to admit that it was responsible and liable for all of Zachariasâ€™ damages, and 
  that its conduct was the sole proximate cause of any and all damages he suffered.Â  
  The remaining requests asked GHA to admit that it had a duty to inspect the 
  hot water heater to unit 62-A and whether GHA had performed such an inspection 
  in the year prior to the incident.Â  GHA did not respond to either discovery 
  request within thirty days.Â  Further, GHA only responded to the Supplemental 
  Interrogatories and Request to Produce on February 5, 2001, two days before 
  the matter was scheduled for trial.Â  GHA did not produce the inspection records 
  for the hot water heaters and never responded to the Requests for Admission.
The matter was initially scheduled for trial on February 7, 2001.Â  
  During the pretrial hearing, Scott moved to have GHAâ€™s lack of response to the 
  Requests for Admission deemed an admission of liability and proximate cause 
  of Zachariasâ€™ injuries pursuant to Rule 36, SCRCP, so that the trial could continue 
  only as to damages.Â  GHA moved to withdraw the admissions for lack of response, 
  averring Scott was on notice that GHA denied liability in the matter because 
  it moved for summary judgment, it denied liability in its answer, and it pled 
  contributory negligence and assumption of the risk as affirmative defenses.Â  
  GHA alleged that, because the deemed admission of liability was at the crux 
  of the case, not regarding a tangential fact, the presentation of the merits 
  would be subserved by allowing the admissions to be withdrawn and Scott would 
  suffer no prejudice in having to prove liability.
Scott claimed that, because GHA refused to comply with any of his discovery 
  requests, he did not have the inspection records necessary to prepare his case.Â  
  Thus, he would be prejudiced and presentation of the merits would not be subserved 
  thereby if GHA were allowed to withdraw their admission of liability.Â  Scott 
  admitted he did not file a motion to compel after GHA failed to respond to the 
  requests for admissions because the issue of liability was deemed admitted under 
  the rule.Â  GHA argued that it had given Scott all the information and records 
  that were available.
The trial court struck GHAâ€™s admissions numbers 3 and 4 regarding liability 
  and negligence.Â  The court found Scott made similar allegations in his complaint 
  and that GHA had denied liability and negligence in its answer.Â  The court was 
  concerned that â€œin every case, then, after issues are joined by pleadings that 
  one or both of the parties will again plead the case by asking for admissions, 
  and we will have a never-ending pleading circumstance by requests for admissions 
  going back and forth between the parties.â€Â  The court noted that the Tort Claims 
  Act requires gross negligence and an admission of liability does not admit gross 
  negligence.Â  In the written order, the court stated â€œthe requests to admit 
  are superfluous to the issues joined in the pleadings and specifically pled 
  in the Plaintiffâ€™s complaint and specifically denied by affirmative defenses 
  in Defendantâ€™s answer.â€Â  The trial court continued the trial to allow 
  Scott to file motions to compel and for GHA to provide Scott with discovery.
Scott filed a motion for reconsideration of the matter.Â  The court denied the 
  motion, holding that â€œwhen issues of fact are joined by answer to the 
  complaint denying assertions in the complaint, then no subsequent failure to 
  respond to discovery as permitted by the Rules of this Court may supercede [sic] 
  and negate those ultimate issues of fact in controversy which are presented 
  by the fundamental pleadings of the parties in the cause before the Court.â€
Scott moved to compel production of GHAâ€™s records concerning the 
  hot water heater.Â  On March 20, 2001, the trial court ordered the production 
  of records and affidavits regarding the search for records within fourteen days.Â  
  GHA failed to produce any documents within the prescribed time period.Â  Scott 
  moved for sanctions for failure to produce the records on April 3, 2001.
On April 9, 2001, GHA filed the affidavit of U.S. Sweeney, Public 
  Housing Coordinator, in which Sweeney declared he gave his attorney all of the 
  documents concerning the hot water heaters.Â  Thereafter, GHA provided copies 
  of inspection records for the last two inspections of the hot water heaters 
  on April 1, 1997, and May 12, 1998.Â  GHA failed to provide requested information 
  regarding other inspections or the purchase, manufacture, maintenance, warranty, 
  or any other requested information regarding the hot water heater.
The matter was rescheduled for trial on April 23, 2001.Â  During the 
  trial, Sweeney testified that more records regarding the hot water heaters were 
  available.Â  During the lunch break, Sweeney obtained two file folders containing 
  numerous inspection documents.Â  The trial court granted Scottâ€™s motion for a 
  mistrial.
Scott filed a second motion for sanctions for contempt of court and 
  failure to participate in discovery.Â  Because GHA had repeatedly denied the 
  existence of the hot water heater records which were readily available, Scott 
  requested that the portion of GHAâ€™s answer in which they denied knowledge of 
  the faulty hot water heaters be struck and that GHA pay Scottâ€™s trial preparation 
  costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The trial court granted Scottâ€™s motion for sanctions 
  as to the trial preparation costs and attorneyâ€™s fees, but the court denied 
  Scottâ€™s request to strike GHAâ€™s denial of knowledge regarding the hot water 
  heaters. 
The case finally went to trial on May 24, 2001.Â  The jury found for 
  GHA.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried by a jury, the appellate 
  courtâ€™s standard of review extends merely to the correction of errors of law.Â  
  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 
  (1976); R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 
  S.C. 424, 540 S.E.2d 113 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  We will not disturb the juryâ€™s factual 
  findings unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence which 
  reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.Â  Townes, 266 S.C. at 85, 221 
  S.E.2d at 775; Brown v. Smalls, 325 S.C. 547, 481 S.E.2d 444 (Ct. App. 
  1997); see also York v. Conway Ford, Inc., 326 S.C. 170, 480 S.E.2d 
  726 (1997) (Court has no power to review matters of fact in action at law except 
  to determine if verdict is wholly unsupported by evidence); Cohens v. Atkins, 
  333 S.C. 345, 509 S.E.2d 286 (Ct. App. 1998) (in action at law on appeal of 
  case tried by jury, jurisdiction of Court of Appeals extends merely to correction 
  of errors of law, and factual finding of jury will not be disturbed unless review 
  of record discloses there is no evidence which reasonably supports juryâ€™s findings).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Scott contends the trial court abused its discretion in allowing 
  GHA to withdraw its deemed admission because: (1) the court erred in ruling 
  that a defendant cannot make an admission that is contrary to denials contained 
  in the answer; (2) the court ignored the requirements for admissions and denials 
  as set forth in Rule 36(a), SCRCP; (3) the court failed to follow the requirements 
  of Rule 36(b), SCRCP, in evaluating GHAâ€™s motion to withdraw the admissions; 
  and (4) the courtâ€™s ruling is inconsistent with the â€œform and substanceâ€ of 
  Rule 36.Â  We agree.
I.Â  ADMISSIONS PURSUANT TO RULE 36(a), 
  SCRCP
The trial court in the underlying case based its ruling, in part, 
  on the fact that any admission pursuant to Rule 36(a) would be in direct conflict 
  with GHAâ€™s answers in its pleadings and went to the ultimate question of liability.Â  

 Whether as previously embodied in prior South Carolina Circuit Court 
  Rule 89 or as currently verbalized in Rule 36, SCRCP, South Carolina has long 
  had the discovery rule that failure to respond to requests for admissions renders 
  any matter listed in the request conclusively admitted for trial.Â  Rule 36(a) [1]  provides that matters for which 
  admissions are requested will be deemed admitted â€œunless, within 30 days 
  after service of the request, or within such shorter or longer time as the court 
  may allow[,] . . . the party to whom the request is directed serves upon the 
  party requesting the admission a written answer or objection addressed to the 
  matter . . . .â€
In reviewing the tenets of Rule 36(a), our courts have repeatedly 
  found that failure to respond to requests for admissions deems matters contained 
  therein admitted for trial, regardless of whether the admission concerns a matter 
  responded to in a partyâ€™s pleadings.Â  In Hatchell v. Jackson, 290 S.C. 
  256, 349 S.E.2d 407 (Ct. App. 1986), Hatchell sued Jackson for fraud and deceit 
  in connection with the sale of a restaurant.Â  Jackson counterclaimed for breach 
  of contract.Â  In his reply to Jacksonâ€™s counterclaim, Hatchell denied he committed 
  a breach of contract, but he failed to respond to Jacksonâ€™s request for admissions.Â  
  The Circuit Court granted summary judgment in favor of Jackson.Â  The Court of 
  Appeals articulated:

Hatchell never responded to Jacksonâ€™s request for admissions; 
  therefore, under South Carolina Circuit Court Rule 89(a), which was then in 
  effect and is now embodied in Rule 36(a) of the new South Carolina Rules of 
  Civil Procedure, each matter of which Jackson sought an admission was deemed 
  admitted.
Based upon the admissions on file, Jackson moved for summary 
  judgment.Â  She maintained the pleadings and admissions on file showed that there 
  was no genuine issue as to any material fact and that she was entitled to judgment 
  as a matter of law on both Hatchellâ€™s claim and her own.

Hatchell, 290 S.C. at 258, 349 S.E.2d at 408.Â  Because genuine issues 
  of material fact still existed even after matters were deemed admitted due to 
  Hatchellâ€™s failure to respond to the request, this Court held the Circuit Court 
  erred in granting summary judgment and reversed.Â  Id. at 259, 349 S.E.2d 
  at 408.
A majority of the Supreme Court, in Hinson-Barr, Inc. v. Pinckard, 292 
  S.C. 267, 356 S.E.2d 115 (1987), concluded that a seller of restaurant equipment 
  was not entitled to summary judgment in its action for breach of contract against 
  a buyer.Â  The dissent, however, pointed out that the buyer failed to respond 
  to the requests for admission:

Under Rule 36(a), SCRCP, all matters contained in a Request 
  for Admission are admitted unless the party serves answers or objects within 
  a certain time.Â  It is undisputed that [B]uyer never responded to Sellerâ€™s second 
  Request for Admissions served on February 28, 1985.Â  By its failure to act, 
  Buyer admitted: (1) that it â€œaccepted the equipment and goods supplied by [Seller] 
  as reflected in the invoices . . .â€; (2) the genuineness of and its acceptance 
  of the invoices and ledger sheets; and (3) that it resold these goods to a third 
  party.Â  These facts are conclusively admitted for the purposes of this litigation 
  since Buyer made no motion to withdraw or amend them.Â  Rule 36(b), SCRCP.

Hinson-Barr, 292 S.C. at 269-70, 356 S.E.2d at 116-17 
  (Ness, C.J., dissenting) (footnote omitted); see also Bakala v. Bakala, 
  Op. No. 25586 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Jan. 27, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 4 
  at 12) (â€œHusband did not respond to Wifeâ€™s request to admit that his interest 
  in Hartig had a value of $300,000 and this fact is therefore deemed admitted 
  under Rule 36(a), SCRCP.â€).
More recently, the Court of Appeals addressed the binding effect 
  of admissions due to a failure to respond to the requests to admit.Â  In Commerce 
  Center of Greenville, Inc. v. W. Powers McElveen & Assocs., Inc., 347 
  S.C. 545, 556 S.E.2d 718 (Ct. App. 2001), a building owner brought an action 
  against an architect and a contractor for damages due to leaky windows.Â  The 
  building owner responded to the requests for admissions, but the owner specifically 
  reserved the right to supplement the response.Â  In reviewing the Circuit Courtâ€™s 
  refusal to allow the contractor to present copies of the admissions to the jury 
  while granting the ownerâ€™s request to amend the admissions, this Court determined 
  that admissions obtained via a failure to respond to a request to admit were 
  just as binding on a party as answers in pleadings or stipulations, absent 
  the grant of an amendment to the admissions:

A party may serve upon any other party a written request for the admission, 
  for purposes of the pending action only, of the truth of any matters within 
  the general rules of discovery that relate to statements or opinions of fact 
  or of the application of law to fact, including the genuineness of any documents 
  described in the request.Â  Rule 36(a), SCRCP.Â  The efficacy of these admissions 
  is akin to the doctrine of judicial estoppel: an admission precludes the admitting 
  party from arguing facts at trial contrary to its responses to a request to 
  admit, absent an amendment to or revocation of the admission as allowed under 
  the rules.Â  See Rule 36(b), SCRCP (â€œAny matter admitted under this rule 
  is conclusively established unless the court on motion permits withdrawal or 
  amendment of the admission.â€); cf. Adams v. Orr, 260 S.C. 92, 
  194 S.E.2d 232 (1973) (affirming trial judgeâ€™s refusal to hold that plaintiffâ€™s 
  lack of responses to several of defendantâ€™s requests to admit were admitted 
  as binding fact because the requests to admit, as worded, were ambiguous and 
  subject to more than one reasonable interpretation).
Admissions under Rule 36 are treated as admissions in pleadings.Â  Muller 
  v. Myrtle Beach Golf & Yacht Club, 303 S.C. 137, 399 S.E.2d 430 (Ct. 
  App. 1990), overruled on other grounds by Myrtle Beach Hosp., Inc. 
  v. City of Myrtle Beach, 341 S.C. 1, 532 S.E.2d 868 (2000); see also 
  James F. Flanagan, South Carolina Civil Procedure 304 (1996) (â€œAdmissions 
  are similar to pleadings.â€); Pulte Home Corp. v. Woodland Nursery & Landscapes, 
  Inc., 230 Ga. App. 455, 496 S.E.2d 546, 548 (1998) (â€œIn form and substance 
  [a response to a request to admit] is comparable to an admission in pleadings 
  or stipulation of facts and as such is generally regarded as a judicial admission 
  rather than evidentiary admission of a party.â€).

Commerce Ctr., 347 S.C. at 554-55, 556 S.E.2d at 723 (footnote omitted).Â  
  Although the Court found the Requests for Admissions were just as binding as 
  pleadings on the parties, it further ruled the Circuit Court was correct in 
  refusing to submit the admissions to the jury because, pursuant to Rule 43, 
  SCRCP, â€œâ€˜pleadings shall not be submitted to the jury for its deliberations.â€™â€Â  
  Id. at 555, 556 S.E.2d at 723 (quoting Rule 43(g), SCRCP).Â  Thus, in 
  our state, requests to admit are not submitted to the jury; rather, the proper 
  course of action is to publish the admissions to the jury.Â  Id.
The federal rule on requests for admissions is substantively similar 
  to our rule.Â  According to Rule 36(a) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, 
  matters for which an admission is sought shall be deemed admitted unless â€œthe 
  party to whom the request is directed serves upon the party requesting the admission 
  a written answer or objection addressed to the matter . . . .â€Â  Rule 36(a), 
  FRCP.Â  The purpose of the rule is to save time and to limit the issues in the 
  case:

[The ruleâ€™s] function is to define and limit the matters 
  in controversy between the parties.
  
Through such definition and limitation, admissions promote both efficiency and 
  economy in resolving disputes.Â  If a point is conceded, litigants need not expend 
  effort in investigations concerning it nor incur expense in presenting evidence 
  to prove it.Â  Judicial administration is also aided.Â  Admissions reduce the 
  time required to try a case.Â  Indeed, they often make summary judgment possible.Â  
  Finally, admissions encourage litigants to evaluate realistically the hazards 
  of trial, and thus tend to promote settlements.
  
The rule is intended to expedite the trial and to relieve 
  the parties of the cost of proving facts that will not be disputed at trial, 
  the truth of which is known to the parties or can be ascertained by reasonable 
  inquiry. 

8A Charles Alan Wright & Arthur R. Miller, Federal Practice and Procedure 
  Â§ 2252 (2d ed. 1994) (footnotes omitted); see also Langer v. Monarch 
  Life Ins. Co., 966 F.2d 786, 803 (3d Cir. 1992) (â€œRule 36 serves two vital 
  purposes, both of which are designed to reduce trial time.Â  Admissions are sought, 
  first to facilitate proof with respect to issues that cannot be eliminated from 
  the case, and secondly, to narrow the issues by eliminating those that can be.â€).
Some federal courts have held that requests for admissions are not 
  objectionable merely because they go to ultimate facts or other issues that 
  must be proven by the plaintiff.Â  See, e.g., Cereghino v. Boeing Co., 
  873 F. Supp. 398, 403 (D. Or. 1994) (holding â€œa request for admission under 
  Rule 36, and a resultant admission, are not improper merely because they . . 
  . relate to an â€˜ultimate fact,â€™ or prove dispositive of the entire case.â€).
The trial judge in the present case erred as a matter of law in finding 
  the admissions made as a result of GHAâ€™s failure to respond to Scottâ€™s requests 
  for admissions were not binding because the admissions would conflict with GHAâ€™s 
  answers in its pleadings.Â  The purpose of Rule 36 is to allow parties to narrow 
  the issues and determine which facts do not need to be proven because they are 
  admitted.Â  Rule 36(a) does not condition the binding effect of requests for 
  admissions upon whether the requests address issues asserted or denied in the 
  pleadings.Â  Whether a request to admit alters the pleadings depends on the language 
  of the particular request to admit.Â  However, if the language of the request 
  for admission specifically goes to an issue in the pleadings, the admission 
  resulting from a partyâ€™s failure to respond to the request may override the 
  pleadings.Â  Despite GHAâ€™s denial of liability and negligence in its pleadings, 
  its failure to respond to Scottâ€™s requests for admissions concerning these issues 
  was binding upon it.
This record exemplifies a paradigm of contumacy and intransigence 
  in the discovery arena.Â  A review of the record does not reveal a paucity 
  or a modicum of response.Â  The activity by GHA demonstrates a nihility in the 
  discovery activity.
Concomitantly, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s finding that the ultimate issue 
  could not be determined by the admission because it was â€œsuperfluousâ€ to the 
  pleadings.Â  
II.Â  AMENDMENT OF ADMISSIONS -- RULE 
  36(b), SCRCP
We now turn to whether the trial court abused its discretion in allowing 
  GHA to withdraw its admissions.
Rule 36(b) delineates the effect of any admission:

Any matter admitted under this rule is conclusively 
  established unless the court on motion permits withdrawal or amendment 
  of the admission.Â  Subject to the provisions of Rule 16 governing amendment 
  of a pre-trial order, the court may permit withdrawal or amendment when the 
  presentation of the merits of the action will be subserved thereby and the party 
  who obtained the admissions fails to satisfy the court that withdrawal or amendment 
  will prejudice him in maintaining his action or defense on the merits.Â  Any 
  admission made by a party under this rule is for the purpose of the pending 
  action only and is not an admission by him for any other purpose.

Rule 36(b), SCRCP (emphasis added).Â  Therefore, a trial court â€œmay allow a 
  party to amend or withdraw its answers to a request to admit when: (1) the presentation 
  of the merits is furthered by the amendment; and (2) the party who obtained 
  the admission cannot demonstrate prejudice because of the amendment.â€Â  Commerce 
  Ctr. of Greenville, Inc. v. W. Powers McElveen & Assocs., Inc., 347 
  S.C. 545, 557, 556 S.E.2d 718, 724 (Ct. App. 2001); see also Tuomey 
  Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., Inc. v. McIntosh, 315 S.C. 189, 191, 432 S.E.2d 485, 487 
  (1985) (â€œRule 36, SCRCP allows amendment of an admission in the discretion of 
  the court when â€˜the merits of the action will be subserved thereby and the party 
  who obtained the admissions fails to satisfy the court that withdrawal or amendment 
  will prejudice him . . . .â€™â€).Â  Federal Rule 36(b), FRCP, similarly provides 
  that â€œthe court may permit withdrawal or amendment when the presentation of 
  the merits of the action will be subserved thereby and the party who obtained 
  the admission fails to satisfy the court that withdrawal or amendment will prejudice 
  that party in maintaining the action or defense on the merits.â€
In the instant case, GHA argued that it should be allowed to withdraw 
  the admission resulting from its lack of response because it â€œaffirmatively 
  denied those specific admissions . . . in the answer . . . and [it] moved for 
  summary judgment . . . .â€Â  GHA asserted Scott would not suffer any prejudice 
  because â€œat any time during this case [Scott] would never have relied upon the 
  fact that we would admit liabilityâ€ due to GHAâ€™s denial in the pleadings.Â  Scott 
  alleged that the merits would not be subserved by letting GHA out of its admissions.Â  
  Because of GHAâ€™s refusal to cooperate with discovery requests, Scott claimed 
  he would be severely prejudiced.Â  In ruling on the matter, the trial court never 
  addressed whether Scott would be prejudiced by the withdrawal of the admissions.Â  
  The court merely focused on the problems that might occur if requests for admissions 
  were allowed to negate denials in pleadings.
The gist and gravamen of the discovery rules mandate full and fair 
  disclosure to prevent a trial from becoming a guessing game or one of ambush 
  for either party.Â  See State Hwy. Depâ€™t v. Booker, 260 S.C. 245, 
  195 S.E.2d 615 (1973); Hodge v. Myers, 255 S.C. 542, 180 S.E.2d 203 (1971).Â  
  Essentially, the rights of discovery articulated by the rules give the attorney 
  the means to prepare for trial.
Discovery is the quintessence of preparation for trial and, when 
  discovery rights are trampled, prejudice must be presumed.Â  See Downey 
  v. Dixon, 294 S.C. 42, 362 S.E.2d 317 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Unless the party 
  who has failed to submit to discovery can show lack of prejudice, reversal is 
  mandated.Â  Samples v. Mitchell, 329 S.C. 105, 495 S.E.2d 213 (Ct. App. 
  1997).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The judge erred in failing to address the prejudice that would be 
  suffered by Scott.Â  Further, it is evident from the record that Scott was prejudiced 
  by the withdrawal of the admission.Â  GHA either denied the existence of or did 
  not provide Scott with discovery records it clearly had access to prior to the 
  first date the trial was scheduled.Â  Scott needed the discovery, which was solely 
  within the control of GHA, in order to prove his case.Â  After the trial court 
  allowed GHA to withdraw its admissions, GHA continued to frustrate Scottâ€™s ability 
  to present his case by first denying the existence of the hot water heater records 
  and then surprising Scott with the records during the middle of trial.Â  The 
  trial court erred in failing to find that Scott was prejudiced.Â  We conclude 
  the trial court committed an abuse of discretion in allowing the withdrawal 
  of the admissions in this case.
Furthermore, we note the trial court had the option to completely strike GHAâ€™s 
  pleadings in the matter as a sanction for its failure to cooperate in discovery.Â  
  See Rule 37(b)(2)(C), SCRCP; see also In re Solomon, 307 
  S.C. 1, 3, 413 S.E.2d 808, 809 (1992) (holding that â€œ[b]ecause [attorney] did 
  not respond [to the requests for admission], however, the allegations were deemed 
  admitted by the trial judge pursuant to Rule 37, SCRCP, and judgment was entered 
  against [client].â€).
CONCLUSION
The trial courtâ€™s decision to allow GHA to withdraw the admissions was based 
  on the judgeâ€™s erroneous belief that requests for admissions could not displace 
  answers in pleadings.Â  The court failed to consider the prejudice that would 
  and did result to Scott due to the withdrawal of the admissions.Â  Accordingly, 
  we REVERSE the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow withdrawal of the admissions, 
  REVERSE the juryâ€™s verdict in the trial, and REMAND the matter 
  for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
 REVERSED and REMANDED.
CONNOR and HUFF, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    The second paragraph of Rule 36(a) was amended effective September 1, 2001, 
    to reflect the change in Rule 29 allowing parties, under certain circumstances, 
    to stipulate to extensions.Â  Because this amendment occurred after the underlying 
    events in the present case, it has no effect on our analysis.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bobby Watson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chesterfield County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3617Â Â 
Heard February 25, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  17, 2003 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of the 
  South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr., of Cheraw; for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Bobby Watson appeals his convictions 
  for first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor and committing a 
  lewd act upon a child under the age of sixteen years, arguing the trial court 
  erred in not allowing him to present surrebuttal testimony in response to the 
  Stateâ€™s reply evidence.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
This action arises out of allegations 
  that Watson abused his girlfriendâ€™s daughter (the victim). 
  [1] Â  In July 1999, the victim, then nine years old, told her grandmother 
  that Watson had sexually abused her for two years.Â  At trial, the victim testified 
  that Watson had made her â€œsuck his private partsâ€ and had â€œgrabbed [her] hand 
  and put it on his front private part and rubbed up and down.â€Â  The victim also 
  testified Watson made her sit on his penis and that he had touched her â€œinside.â€Â  
  The victim stated the incidents occurred when she stayed with her mother, her 
  brother, and Watson in a two-bedroom trailer and also at her grandmotherâ€™s house.Â  

Watson denied the allegations and maintained 
  they resulted from the fact that his girlfriend was mad at him for cheating 
  on her, as was her family; he contended the victim â€œvery seldom was in our house.â€Â  
  Watson testified that he and his girlfriend lived in a trailer with their son, 
  and that the victim did not live with them during the time the acts allegedly 
  occurred, when the victim was seven to nine.Â  Rather, the victim stayed with 
  her grandmother â€œpractically all the timeâ€ and â€œwas a visitor in [his] home 
  [the trailer].â€Â  Watson asserted that he was never left alone with the victim.Â  
  He also presented a defense theory that the allegations could have been the 
  product of suggested memories based on the victim having seen pornographic movies 
  and a sex channel on television that the victimâ€™s grandmother allegedly subscribed 
  to. [2] Â  He alternatively asserted that 
  if there was any sexual abuse, it was committed by someone else.Â  
In reply, the State presented the testimony of 
  a neighbor, who stated that she often saw Watson, his girlfriend, their son, 
  and the victim at the trailer from 1997 to 1999, although the victim would sometimes 
  stay at her grandparentsâ€™ house.Â  The neighbor also testified that she went 
  to the trailer to borrow something one day and Watson was home with just his 
  son and the victim.Â  During cross-examination, the witness admitted having a 
  criminal record involving fraudulent checks and shoplifting.Â  
A jury convicted Watson of first-degree CSC with 
  a minor and committing a lewd act upon a child under the age of sixteen years.Â  
  The trial court sentenced him to thirty years in prison for the CSC charge and 
  a concurrent fifteen years for the charge of committing a lewd act.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Watson contends he is entitled to a new trial based 
  on the trial courtâ€™s failure to allow him to present surrebuttal testimony. 

After the State presented reply testimony from 
  Watsonâ€™s neighbor, the following exchange occurred:

MRS. RIVERS [Defense counsel]:Â  Your Honor, I would ask to 
  put the defendant on the stand for rebuttal.
MS. MAYES [State]:Â  I know of absolutely no provision under 
  the law of the Rules of Evidence that allows that, Your Honor.
THE COURT:Â  I donâ€™t either.
Any matters of law at this time?Â 

The parties then proceeded to discuss jury charges.Â  
  Thereafter, Watson himself addressed the court and stated, â€œYour Honor, I want 
  to ask you can I comment on what this testimony was because this lady right 
  here that just stated this testimony was evicted.Â  Katrina, the mother of the 
  victim, lived with this woman.â€Â  Watson told the court that his father would 
  also be willing to testify.Â  The court stated:Â  â€œIâ€™m sorry.Â  I am not allowed 
  under procedure to let that happen.Â  That was reply from the State after you 
  put up your defense, Mr. Watson.â€Â  
On appeal, Watsonâ€™s appellate counsel argues the 
  trial court erred in failing to exercise its discretion or, alternatively, abused 
  its discretion, when it did not allow the defense to present surrebuttal testimony 
  to address allegedly new matter brought out in the Stateâ€™s reply evidence.Â  
  Counsel contends that, contrary to the trial courtâ€™s ruling, surrebuttal testimony 
  is allowed under South Carolina law, citing Camlin v. Bi-Lo, Inc. [3]  and State v. Summer [4]  as supporting authority.
Initially, we find it questionable whether this 
  issue was preserved for consideration on direct appeal as this argument appears 
  to be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  When the trial court denied the 
  request to present the additional testimony, it did so based on its apparent 
  belief that additional testimony was not allowed after the Stateâ€™s reply.Â  No 
  argument was raised by the defense that such surrebuttal testimony is, in fact, 
  allowed in the courtâ€™s discretion. [5] Â  
On the merits, contrary to the trial courtâ€™s statement 
  that it was â€œnot allowed under procedure to let that happen,â€ some authorities 
  note that there are occasions when the trial court may allow surrebuttal testimony 
  in its discretion:

Surrebuttal is appropriate when, in the judgeâ€™s discretion, 
  new matter or new facts are injected for the first time in rebuttal[,] especially 
  where the evidence offered in surrebuttal is for the first time made competent 
  by the evidence introduced by plaintiff in rebuttal.
On the other hand, if the evidence sought to be introduced 
  in surrebuttal could or should have been introduced at an earlier stage, its 
  admission or rejection is a matter for the discretion of the trial court, as 
  where the evidence is cumulative, or where there is no sufficient excuse for 
  not introducing the evidence in chief at the proper time. 
  [6] 

South Carolina courts have approved the 
  use of surrebuttal testimony in the discretion of the trial court.Â  In Goethe 
  v. Browning, [7]  our supreme 
  court stated:Â  â€œAdmission of evidence in surrebuttal is very much in the discretion 
  of the trial judge.â€ [8] Â  In 
  State v. Summer, the court observed:Â  â€œ[I]f the plaintiff [or the prosecution 
  in a criminal case] in reply puts new matter in evidence, or makes a new case 
  different from that at first made out, it becomes the right of the defendant 
  to call witnesses in surrebuttal.â€ [9] Â  Further, in Camlin v. Bi-Lo, 
  Inc., we stated:Â  â€œA defendant has a right to respond to new evidence given 
  in reply.â€ [10] Â  
Thus, the trial court erred when it stated it was 
  not allowed to permit additional testimony; however, we conclude Watson has 
  suffered no prejudice warranting reversal, in any event, as the Stateâ€™s reply 
  witness did not raise any new evidence.Â  The reply witnessâ€™s testimony that 
  she saw the victim, her younger brother, her mother, and Watson living together 
  in the trailer and that she saw Watson home alone with the victim and her younger 
  brother was cumulative to the testimony of the victim and her grandmother, who 
  both testified during the Stateâ€™s case-in-chief that Watson had been alone with 
  the victim and her younger brother on nights when his girlfriend was working, 
  and that the victim stayed at the trailer with him.Â  Additionally, we note the 
  victim testified the abuse occurred not only when her mother was gone, but also 
  while her mother was home asleep.Â  Finally, the evidence Watson would have offered, 
  i.e., that the neighbor had been evicted and had lived with his ex-girlfriend, 
  were matters going to credibility that could have been brought out during cross-examination.Â  
  Defense counsel did elicit on cross-examination the fact that the neighbor had 
  prior convictions so as to attack her credibility.Â  Accordingly, Watsonâ€™s conviction 
  and sentence are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and SHULER, J., concur.   

 
   
    [1] Â  Although the victim was not his child, Watson and his girlfriend 
    did have one child together, a son.Â  Â Â 

 
   
    [2] Â  During an interview with a psychologist, the victim reported having 
    briefly seen, on two occasions, portions of sexually explicit videotapes that 
    were mistakenly put in the VCR.Â  Her grandmother (or another adult), however, 
    had realized the mistake and retrieved them.Â  

 
   [3] Â  311 S.C. 197, 428 S.E.2d 6 (Ct. App. 1993).

 
   [4] Â  55 S.C. 32, 32 S.E. 771 (1899).

 
   [5] Â  See State v. Huggins, 
    336 S.C. 200, 205, 519 S.E.2d 574, 577 (1999) (â€œIt is well-settled that issues 
    may not be raised for the first time on appeal.â€).Â  

 
   [6] Â  88 C.J.S. Trial Â§ 197 (2001) (footnote 
    omitted).

 
   [7] Â  146 S.C. 7, 143 S.E. 362 (1928).

 
   [8] Â  Id. at 18, 143 S.E. at 366.

 
   [9] Â  55 S.C. at 40, 32 S.E. at 774 (citation omitted).

 
   
    [10]  311 S.C. at 200, 428 S.E.2d at 8 (citing Strait v. City of Rock 
    Hill, 104 S.C. 116, 88 S.E. 469 (1916)).

Shannon v. Shannon

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Diane Shannon, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
George Shannon, Appellant.
      
    
  



  
    
      
        George L. Shannon, Appellant,
      
    
  


v.

  
    
      
        Teresa Diane Shannon, Respondent.
      
    
  


 
Appeal From Kershaw County
Gerald C. Smoak, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3618
Heard February 13, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  17, 2003

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED


  
    
      
James W. Corley, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Carlos W. Gibbons, Jr., of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  In this post-divorce 
  domestic action, George Shannon (Husband) appeals an order of the family court 
  holding him in contempt and denying his plea for termination or modification 
  of his alimony obligation to Diane Shannon (Wife).Â  We affirm in part, reverse 
  in part, and remand.
BACKGROUND
The parties were divorced by order of the family 
  court in 1997.Â  The divorce decree provides, inter alia, that Husband is to 
  pay Wife $400 per month in periodic alimony with all payments to be made through 
  the court.Â  
On February 16, 1999, Wife was reported as a missing 
  person.Â  Her whereabouts have not been known since that date.Â  After her disappearance, 
  a conservatorship was established on Wifeâ€™s behalf. 
Husband instituted this action in April of 2001 
  seeking termination of his alimony obligation to Wife.Â  Alternatively, Husband 
  sought modification of his alimony obligation, retroactive to the date Wife 
  was reported missing.Â  First Union Bank, in its capacity as Wifeâ€™s court-appointed 
  conservator, arranged for Wife to have legal representation.Â  Wifeâ€™s answer 
  to the complaint denied Husbandâ€™s entitlement to the relief sought, and contained 
  a counterclaim seeking an award of attorney fees and costs. Â Additionally, 
  because Husband was in arrears on his alimony payments, the family court issued 
  a rule to show cause why Husband should not be held in contempt for failure 
  to pay alimony. [1]   
After a hearing on both actions, the court denied 
  Husbandâ€™s plea for relief from his alimony support obligation and held him in 
  contempt for failure to pay alimony.Â  The court determined his arrearage was 
  $7,763 as of the date of the order.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may 
  find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992); 
  Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 546, 466 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  

Discussion
Husband asserts the family court erred 
  in failing to grant him relief from his alimony obligation in light of Wifeâ€™s 
  continued status as a missing person.Â  We agree.
In denying Husband any relief from his alimony 
  obligation, the family court reasoned that Wifeâ€™s status as a missing person 
  is not, standing alone, a sufficient basis to terminate or suspend Husbandâ€™s 
  support obligation.Â  The court further reasoned that in the event Wife reappears, 
  she would be left without a remedy to collect any support obligation owed.Â  
  We agree with Husband that the family courtâ€™s reasoning as to this issue is 
  flawed.
An award of periodic alimony may be modified pursuant 
  to South Carolina Code Annotated section 20-3-170 (1985).Â  That statute provides:

Whenever [a spouse] . . . has been required to make [to] 
  his or her spouse any periodic payments of alimony and the circumstances of 
  the parties or the financial ability of the spouse making the periodic payments 
  shall have changed since the rendition of such judgment, either party may apply 
  to the court which rendered the judgment for an order and judgment decreasing 
  or increasing the amount of such alimony payments or terminating such payments. 


In order to justify modification or termination 
  of an alimony award, the changes in circumstances must be substantial or material.Â  
  Eubank v. Eubank, 347 S.C. 367, 372, 555 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. App. 2001).
As alleged in the complaint and admitted in the 
  answer, Wifeâ€™s whereabouts have not been known since on or before February 16, 
  1999.Â  Additionally, the record contains no evidence Wife is actually receiving 
  or in any way personally benefiting from Husbandâ€™s alimony payments.Â  The basic 
  purpose of alimony is to substitute for the support which is â€œnormally incident 
  to the marital relationship.â€Â  McNaughton v. McNaughton, 258 S.C. 554, 
  558, 189 S.E.2d 820, 822 (1972).Â  If these parties were not divorced, Husband 
  would have no obligation to provide financial support for a wife who chose to 
  disappear.
In our view, Wifeâ€™s sustained disappearance constitutes a 
  substantial change in the partiesâ€™ circumstances warranting a modification of 
  Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation.Â  Under the extraordinary circumstances of this 
  case, we are simply unable to conclude that the ends of justice and equity will 
  be served by requiring Husband to continue making alimony payments until such 
  time as Wife either reappears or is declared dead.Â  
We hold the peculiar circumstances of this case 
  warrant a modification amounting to suspension of Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation 
  retroactive to the date this litigation was commenced.Â  We therefore reverse 
  the family courtâ€™s order and remand the case for recalculation of Husbandâ€™s 
  arrearage consistent with this holding.
Additional considerations convince us this result 
  is equitable.Â  Although Husband did not seek modification, termination, or suspension 
  of his alimony obligation on any ground other than Wifeâ€™s continued status as 
  a missing person, his financial circumstances have changed since the court originally 
  ordered alimony.Â  He lost his job and now earns significantly less than at the 
  time of the divorce.Â  Additionally, although the court awarded custody of the 
  coupleâ€™s children to Wife, they were placed in Husbandâ€™s care before Wifeâ€™s 
  disappearance, and he has received no child support from Wife or her conservator.Â  

Regarding the family courtâ€™s concern that Wife, 
  should she reappear, will be without legal means to recover the amount of support 
  that would have been due her if Husbandâ€™s obligation had not been suspended, 
  we note nothing prevents Wife from petitioning the family court to lift the 
  suspension ordered herein and to revisit the issue of alimony pursuant to the 
  provisions of section 20-3-170.Â  Our holding is not intended to prevent Wife 
  from pursuing such legal recourse should she reappear.Â  
Further, our decision is not intended to disturb the family 
  courtâ€™s findings as to contempt or any arrearage Husband accumulated prior to 
  the commencement of this action.Â  We are aware of no authority, and Husband 
  cites none, entitling a spouse to cease making court-ordered alimony payments 
  in the absence of a judicial order authorizing such relief.Â  
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the family court 
  is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.Â  

CURETON and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Rule to Show Cause refers to Husbandâ€™s failure 
    to pay child support rather than alimony.Â  We determine that to be merely 
    a clerical oversight.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ex Parte: Ned Polk, Jr. and York County Bail Agent,       
Appellants,
In Re:
State of South Carolina,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Henry Zbigniew Bartinicki,       
Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3619
Submitted January 13, 2003 - Filed March 
  31, 2003

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
James W. Boyd, of Rock Hill, for Appellants.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John 
  McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Assistant 
  Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, of Columbia;Â  Daniel Dewitt Hall, of York; 
  and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York; for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This is a bond estreatment 
  case.Â  The sole issue on appeal concerns whether the trial court erred in failing 
  to consider the cost to the State of Henry Zbigniew Bartinickiâ€™s failure to 
  appear in court in ordering the estreatment of his bond.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Bartinicki was arrested and charged 
  with trafficking in cocaine, distribution of marijuana, distribution of cocaine 
  within the proximity of a school, and distribution of marijuana within the proximity 
  of a school.Â  He was released on an appearance bond in the amount $37,000, with 
  Ned Polk, Jr., of York County Bail Agent, signing as surety.Â  Bartinicki failed 
  to appear in court when called on April 23, 2001, September 4, 2001, and September 
  10, 2001.Â  A bench warrant was issued for his arrest on September 12, 2001.Â  
  He again failed to appear in court when his case was called onÂ  September 24, 
  October 8, and October 22, 2001.Â  On November 6, 2001, he was tried in his absence 
  and found guilty.
The circuit court held a bond estreatment 
  hearing on November 7, 2001.Â  Ned Polk, Sr. appeared on behalf of York County 
  Bail Agent in the place of his son, Ned Polk, Jr.Â  Polk requested additional 
  time to find Bartinicki, and requested that the bond be estreated in installments 
  over a six month period rather than in a lump sum.Â  In conjunction with this 
  request, the attorney for the surety asked the court to consider the cost to 
  the State for Bartinickiâ€™s trial, asserting the cost was less than the total 
  amount of the bond.Â  The trial court declined to take the cost of the trial 
  into account, reasoning only that Bartinicki was not yet in custody.
In a ruling from the bench and by amended order 
  dated November 22, 2001, the court directed that if Bartinicki was produced 
  within seven days of the hearing, the bond would not be estreated.Â  The order 
  further provided that, in the event Bartinicki was not produced within seven 
  days, one-fourth of the bond would be estreated and, thereafter, one-fourth 
  of the original amount of the bond would be estreated every month until Bartinicki 
  was produced or the bond was exhausted.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Polk asserts the trial court 
  erred in failing to consider the cost to the State in reaching its decision 
  as to estreatment.Â  We agree.
Initially, we disagree with the Stateâ€™s assertion that 
  Polk failed to raise the issue of remission to the trial court.Â  Our reading 
  of the record convinces us the trial judge understood the issue of remission 
  to have been before him for consideration inasmuch as the court ruled on the 
  issue of considering the cost to the State resulting from Bartinickiâ€™s failure 
  to appear.
Further, we hold the court erred in refusing to consider 
  the Stateâ€™s costs.Â  The overriding purpose of requiring a criminal defendant 
  to post bond before his release from custody is to insure his appearance at 
  trial.Â  State v. Boatwright, 310 S.C. 281, 285, 423 S.E.2d 139, 141 (1992) 
  (Toal, J., dissenting).Â  As guarantor, the surety on an appearance bond undertakes 
  the risk of forfeiture in the event the defendant does not appear for trial.Â  
  Pride v. Anders, 266 S.C. 338, 341, 223 S.E.2d 184, 186 (1976).Â  Thus, 
  the possible forfeiture of bond is incentive for sureties to ensure the appearance 
  of the defendant. Â The issue of whether a bond forfeiture should be remitted, 
  and if so, to what extent, is vested in the discretion of the trial judge.Â  
  State v. Workman, 274 S.C. 341, 343, 263 S.E.2d 865, 866 (1980);Â  State 
  v. Holloway, 262 S.C. 552, 557, 206 S.E.2d 822, 824 (1974).
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-70 (2002) provides: 


If a defendant fails to appear 
  at a court proceeding to which he has been summoned, the court must issue a 
  bench warrant for the defendant.Â  If the surety fails to surrender the defendant 
  or place a hold on the defendant's release from incarceration, commitment, or 
  institutionalization within thirty days of the issuance of the bench warrant, 
  the bond shall be forfeited.Â  At any time before execution is issued on a judgment 
  of forfeiture against a defendant or his surety, the court may direct that the 
  judgment be remitted in whole or in part, upon conditions as the court may impose, 
  if it appears that justice requires the remission of part or all of the judgment.Â  
  In making a determination as to remission of the judgment, the court shall 
  consider the costs to the State or any county or municipality resulting 
  from the necessity to continue or terminate the defendant's trial and the efforts 
  of law enforcement officers or agencies to locate the defendant.Â  The court 
  in its discretion may permit the surety to pay the estreatment in installments 
  for a period of up to six months.Â  If at any time during the period in which 
  installments are to be paid the defendant is surrendered to the appropriate 
  detention facility and the surety complies with the re-commitment procedures, 
  the surety shall be relieved of any further liability.

(emphasis added).
Where the terms of a statute are clear and unambiguous, 
  there is no room for construction and the court must apply such terms according 
  to their literal meaning.Â  Gentry v. Yonce, 337 S.C. 1, 13, 522 S.E.2d 
  137, 143 (1999).Â  An appellate court cannot construe a statute without regard 
  to its plain meaning.Â  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. 
  Control, 348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410, 414 (2002).Â  Neither may it 
  resort to a forced interpretation in an attempt to expand or limit the scope 
  of a statute.Â  Id.
Unquestionably, Bartinickiâ€™s bond was forfeited and 
  the trial court properly entered judgment on the bond.Â  However, Â§ 38-53-70 
  unambiguously provides that the trial court must consider the costs to the State 
  in determining remission of the judgment on a forfeited bond.Â  Therefore, the 
  trial judge abused his discretion in failing to consider the costs to the State.Â  
  We note, however, that in determining whether any remission of the judgment 
  is warranted, the trial court is not limited to considering only the actual 
  cost to the State.Â  Our courts have held the following factors, at the least, 
  should be considered in determining whether, and to what extent, the bond should 
  be remitted:Â  (1) the purpose of the bond;Â  (2) the nature and wilfulness of 
  the default;Â  (3) any prejudice or additional expense resulting to the State.Â  
  Boatwright, 310 S.C. at 287, 423 S.E.2d at 142-43;Â  Workman, 274 
  S.C. at 343, 263 S.E.2d at 866.
In conclusion, we hold, while the decision regarding 
  remission is within the discretion of the trial court, the court should consider, 
  at a minimum, the costs to the State as well as the purpose of the bond and 
  the nature and willfulness of the default in determining whether, and to what 
  extent, a bond forfeiture should be remitted. 
  [1] Â  Accordingly, we reverse and remand the case for further proceedings 
  consistent with this opinion.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF and SHULER, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] In Boatwright, the dissent, citing Workman, indicated 
    the court should â€œat least considerâ€ the above three factors, suggesting that 
    other factors may be considered as well.Â  Boatwright, 310 S.C. at 287, 
    423 S.E.2d at 142-43.Â  Thus, it appears the trial court may consider the fact 
    that the defendant, Bartinicki, was not in custody at the time of the bond 
    estreatment hearing in determining whether, and if so to what extent, the 
    bond should be remitted.Â  At any rate, this fact would clearly be appropriate 
    for consideration in conjunction with the courtâ€™s deliberation of the costs 
    to the State.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Dr. Treadwell Campbell, Appellant,
  v.
Marion County Hospital District, d/b/a The Mullins Hospital,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marion County
John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3620
Heard March 12, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  31, 2003

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  and REMANDED


  
    
      
Brenda Reddix Smalls, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Ralph W. Barbier and Joseph M. Kahn, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 ANDERSON, J.:Â  Dr. Treadwell Campbell (Dr. Campbell) sued 
  Marion County Hospital District, d/b/a The Mullins Hospital (the Hospital), 
  under the South Carolina Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) for information including, 
  among other things, salaries, compensation, benefits, and bonuses offered to 
  all physicians recruited by the Hospital, as well as the prices paid for physician 
  practices purchased by the Hospital.Â  The Circuit Court ordered the Hospital 
  to disclose a portion of the requested information, but it further held that 
  information regarding physiciansâ€™ salaries, compensation, and purchase prices 
  of practices were â€œtrade secrets.â€Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and 
  remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In relation to a pending lawsuit, Dr. Campbell 
  requested that the Hospital produce certain information pursuant to the FOIA.Â  
  Specifically, Dr. Campbell requested the Hospital provide information regarding: 
  (1) the compensation, benefits, and bonuses offered to physicians recruited 
  by the Hospital from 1988 to 1999; (2) the prices paid for the purchase of physician 
  practices; (3) the salaries of physicians whose practices were purchased by 
  the Hospital; (4) the salaries of specific physicians; (5) the amount of rent 
  paid to physician practices since 1988; and (6) the purchase price and a copy 
  of the invoice of purchase if the Hospital purchased the Marion Medical Group.Â  
  The Hospital indicated it would provide the information regarding the amount 
  of rent paid to any physician or physician practice since 1988, but Dr. Campbell 
  would have to post a deposit of $1,500 to cover the expenses of researching 
  and copying the information.Â  The Hospital refused to provide any of the other 
  information stating information regarding physicians recruited, but not employed, 
  by the Hospital was incidental to proposed contractual arrangements and thus 
  exempt from disclosure.Â  The Hospital asserted the requested information regarding 
  physiciansâ€™ salaries and the purchase prices of physician practices constituted 
  â€œtrade secretsâ€ which were exempt from disclosure under the FOIA.
Dr. Campbell sued the Hospital under the FOIA, requesting that the 
  Circuit Court (1) deem the withheld information to be public information within 
  the meaning of the FOIA; (2) enjoin the Hospital from withholding the information; 
  and (3) award Dr. Campbell costs and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The Hospital denied the 
  allegations of the complaint and maintained the allegations failed to state 
  a claim upon which relief could be granted.Â  With the exception of the amounts 
  of physician lease fees, the Hospital averred the requested information was 
  exempt from disclosure as â€œtrade secrets.â€Â  Both parties moved for summary judgment.
After hearing arguments from both parties, the Circuit Court judge 
  issued an order: (1) finding the information regarding physicians recruited, 
  but not actually hired, by the Hospital was exempt from disclosure; (2) requiring 
  the Hospital to produce the information relating to physiciansâ€™ salaries and 
  the purchase price of practices, but barring Dr. Campbell from disclosing the 
  information to third parties; (3) directing the Hospital to disclose information 
  relating to the rents paid to physician practices; (4) compelling Dr. Campbell 
  to pay a $500 deposit to cover the costs of providing the information; and (5) 
  concluding Dr. Campbell was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Dr. Campbell filed 
  a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration, which was denied by the Circuit 
  Court.
ISSUES

  
    
       I.
       
  Did the Circuit Court err in holding that Dr. Campbellâ€™s request for disclosure 
  of physiciansâ€™ salaries, bonuses, compensation, and purchase prices of physician 
  practices constituted â€œtrade secretsâ€ requiring a protective order?
    
    
       II.
       
  Did the Circuit Court err in refusing to award attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to 
  Dr. Campbell where he prevailed and the court ordered the production of all 
  the information requested from the Hospital?
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Although Dr. Campbell filed a motion for summary judgment, he actually 
  requested the Circuit Court to declare whether the withheld information was 
  exempt under the FOIA.
Declaratory judgments in and of themselves are neither legal nor equitable.Â  
  See Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 400 S.E.2d 781 (1991); 
  Wiedemann v. Town of Hilton Head Island, 344 S.C. 233, 542 S.E.2d 752 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The standard of review for a declaratory judgment action is 
  therefore determined by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Doe v. South 
  Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n, 347 S.C. 642, 
  557 S.E.2d 670 (2001); Wiedemann, 344 S.C. at 236, 542 S.E.2d at 753; 
  see also Travelers Indem. Co. v. Auto World, 334 S.C. 137, 511 
  S.E.2d 692 (Ct. App. 1999) (suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor 
  equitable, but is determined by nature of underlying issue).
A declaratory judgment action under the FOIA to determine whether certain information 
  should be disclosed is an action at law.Â  See South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n 
  v. Gaston Copper Recycling Corp., 316 S.C. 163, 447 S.E.2d 843 (1994).Â  
  In an action at law tried without a jury, the appellate court standard of review 
  extends only to the correction of errors of law.Â  Crary v. Djebelli, 
  329 S.C. 385, 496 S.E.2d 21 (1998); Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 
  266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976); Okatie River v. Southeastern Site Prep, 
  Op. No. 3582 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Jan. 6, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 1 at 
  32).Â  Thus, the trial courtâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal 
  unless a review of the record discloses that there is no evidence which reasonably 
  supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 
  606, 533 S.E.2d 886 (2000); Townes, 266 S.C. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 775; 
  Barnacle Broad., Inc. v. Baker Broad., Inc., 343 S.C. 140, 538 S.E.2d 
  672 (Ct. App. 2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)
The South Carolina Freedom of Information Act is 
  codified as sections 30-4-10 to â€“165 in the South Carolina Code.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 30-4-10 to â€“165 (1991 & Supp. 2002).Â  The FOIA provides:

The General Assembly finds that it is vital in a democratic
